reviewText:
Brutal and downright-diffuclt, XCOM: Enemy Unknown's isometric, turn-based strategy gameplay serves as a barometer not just for the sequel to match -- but also as a standard for other games. With frenetic sequences down a narrow aisle with four Mutons suppressing you down or having a Sectoid Commander mind-controlling your soldier without any retaliation, you'll find yourself knee-deep and swimming in pockets of endless fun and gratification as you go from calm to subdued within seconds.

The skills and perks are a great way for the soldiers to level up, granting you various better equipments when you research weapons and armor. The game's core is very simplistic but yet engaging and compelling for those wanting that strategic itch.

I decided to play for an hour but that escalated into something else. XCOM: Enemy Unknown is brilliant and challenging -- but that's what makes it fun and amazing.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: XCOM: Enemy Unknown
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Turn-Based Strategy; RPG; Tactical Strategy; Gridiron-Battles
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 25-50 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWXCOM: Enemy Unknown is hands-down a very fun game.  The battles are grid-style, turn-based, squad-based-strategy-RPG in nature.  And the gameplay that doesn't occur during the battles, like base management and the like, is very captivating and fun.  That adds up to a great all around experience of a hybrid strategy/RPG/management game.

Put simply, this is a masterfully crafted game.  It has many elements of many styles of games, and the developers did a great job finding the perfect mosaic of the concepts.  The battles are strategic, challenging, and have just the right amount of luck based influence.  The meta-game action between battles keeps you engaged and always trying to reach that next upgradeâ€” this makes it impossible to stop playing sometimes. It can be that addictive.

I suppose XCOM: Enemy Unknown isn't really that innovative, but something about it just feels very fresh and different.  There are many games out there that produce a similar experience, but not many can achieve a level of quality this does.  Any fans of strategic, tactical, RPG-ish, managerial type games should check out this game.

reviewText:
Not being a fan of strategy games, I was skeptic when buying what would become my all-time favorite game. Now, first off, this is not Real-Time Strategy, this is Turn-Based Strategy, and the only previous experience I had with such titles was tabletop games, and Pokemon. So I gave it a shot.

The game is set during the begining of a war with extraterrestrial beings. You are made Commander of the Extraterrestrial Combat Unit, XCOM for short and lead a global effort to push back the invasion. With a Council overseeing you, and people being abducted every day, this is no easy task.

How do you stop the alien menace? The gameplay is mainly divided into two parts: all of the gameplay that happens at the base (i.e. sending air support, investigating alien technology, changing your soldiers' names and looks, promoting soldiers, choosing countries to support, and expanding your base) and the gameplay that takes place in the battlefield, with your international squad of customized elite soldiers (i.e. moving them, shooting at aliens, recovering resources, saving civilians caught in the cross-fire). Both parts are incredibly well done and very fun to play.

Now, when I say elite soldiers you might think this is easy, but make no mistake, this game is unforgiving, sometimes to ridiculous extents in higher difficulties. It should prove a challenge to beat the game even on Normal, as countries stop giving you their support and the world crumbles around you. And, as it is no longer common in most AAA games, death really does matter in this game. Do you have a Sniper Major who you spent hours costumizing, giving medals to, promoting and always saves your team? One lucky shot by the enemy and you have him no longer.

If you like intelligent, highly customizable, hard but enjoyable games this one is for you.

And don't even get me started on how good the DLC is.

reviewText:
X-COM: UFO Defense was a terrifying and terrific game that was well overdue for a modern update, and what better developer than Firaxis to take up the charge?

XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and Enemy Within) offers a modern take on a great theme: aliens have arrived and they're taking over the Earth. They're going to succeed, unless you, the player, stops them. The player takes over the role of The Commander of XCOM, a last-ditch international cooperative force of the best of the best of humanity's soldiers, scientists, engineers, and pilots. Your squads of soldiers will be deployed on missions to recover alien technology, defeat alien terror attacks, and uncover the mystery of the invasion in hopes of ultimately thwarting it. This side of the game occurs on a turn-based tactical combat layer that will be familiar to those of you who've played the original, or even games like Final Fantasy Tactics and the like. For a good chunk of the game, the aliens have better guns than you and are often statistically superior, so your soldiers must make good use of cover and positioning to overcome that challenge.

The rest of the game (research technology, training soldiers, building equipment/facilities, managing aircraft) occurs on a base management strategy layer. It's a fairly light take as far as management games go, but it gets the job done, and there are multiple ways to go about things. You need to deploy your squads, aircraft, and launch satellites in such a way as to minimize global panic and keep your benefactors (countries) on your side

One of the best parts about XCOM is that it mirrored facets of the original well: the game can be deadly. You can lose your campaign, and then boom, game over, the aliens won. A tactical battle can quickly go awry, resulting in you losing your top squad of soldiers and forcing you to field newbies once more. This terror is best exemplified in the game's Ironman Mode, which only allows a single autosave file, and the game autosaves with every single turn. Lose the campaign, and your save is deleted. Combine that with one of the harder difficulties (Classic or Impossible), and difficulty junkies will surely get their fill.

All in all one of the best strategy games to come out in the past decade. The expansion (Enemy Within) and other DLC (Slingshot) add more missions and options to the game in a great way. A must buy for tactical/strategy lovers and a great first strategy" game for newcomers
date: though they may want to start on Easy or Normal."

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all time, XCOM: Enemy Unknown successfully combines deep tactical gameplay and RPG elements into a single, glorious package.  Due to recent extraterrestrial attacks, the XCOM Project has been activated and you have been appointed as its commander.  Your duties include directing the initiative's research, sending order to the engineering department, selecting and hiring the best soldiers for the job, and commanding said soldiers in battle.  You'll also be building and modifying satellites and aircraft to provide intel and defense against the alien threat as well.

As the war progresses, the alien invasion forces will become increasingly dangerous.  New alien types with more advanced equipment and abilities will show up throughout the war to catch XCOM offguard.  Fortunately, this is where your research department tips the scales in your favor.  After eliminating an enemy threat you will acquire alien materials and corpses that your scientists will be able to study.  Common results from these studies include new gear options for your soldiers, additional aircraft and air-based weaponry, new facilities to build in your base, and more that will further your cause.  I was always very excited when my research resulted in a new piece of gear based on alien tech that was significantly more efficient than what I had previously used.

In addition to improvements to their gear, your soldiers will gain promotions as they acquire experience in combat.  Each of the four classes has a unique tech three that they will progress down as you see fit.  Each rank allows you to choose one of two options that will offer new abilities to use or passive buffs to the unit's overall efficiency.  One Heavy soldier may be built around specializing with his rocket launcher, another might be entirely focused on maximizing their machine  gun capabilities, and a third might have a combination skills from both skill lines.

There are two other aspects of XCOM that I feel need to be mentioned in addition to the standard mechanics: Second Wave and Long War.  Second Wave is a menu full of options that is unlocked after having completed the game once.  These drastically change the mechanics of the game and include changes such as a semi-randomized skill tree for your units where one, or potentially both, of their options for a particular rank offer skills that are not usually allowed to that profession.  For example, you might have an Assault trooper who has an advanced talent with medicine that is capable of healing their allies for significantly more health, an ability that is usually Support-only.

Long War, on the other hand, is an unofficial mod created by players who saw the opportunity to futher improve an already great game.  Though there are plenty of mods out there, none that I have seen can come close to comparing to the ambition shown in Long War.  I won't go into the details here but I find that it improves almost every aspect of the game for me.  If you're interested, read more on it here:    http://www.nexusmods.com/xcom/mods/88/?

There are very few people that I wouldn't recommend this game to.  The variety of difficulty options makes it an enjoyable game whether you're a more casual player of if you're a hardcore masochist (I'm looking at you Impossible/Ironman).  The mechanics are great, the atmosphere is fantastic, and everyone who I've spoken to who has played has had numerous stories to share that are a lot of fun to hear.  Just remember, you'll be losing a lot of soldier that you've customized grown attached to.

Now stop reading and save the world from the alien menace, Commander!

reviewText:
There are very few games like XCom Enemy Unknown made today. Strategy games apart from sims are far and few between, especially made by AAA studios and publishers. This game was no different, as it took a very long time to get developed since the publisher originally wanted to make it a first person shooter.

Instead what we got is a delightful return to form for the series. XCom Enemy Unknown is a game where you play as the commander of a team that specializes in stopping an alien invasion of the planet Earth. The game is a turn based strategy game and heavy in things like cover and approaching carefully. Your squad of soldiers likewise is heavily customizeable, and as you complete more missions they grow identities of their own.

What amuses me is how the game likewise punishes you for failure. There's a setting in the game called Ironman" mode which disables quicksaving. What this does is force you to either restart an entire mission from the start
date: or bite the bullet and move on if one of your favorite squad members dies. Because you can only level up soldiers by completing missions
recommended: this mode makes you play extra carefully so you can get everyone out alive.\n\nEnemy Unknown is a refreshing change of pace from the nonstop first person shooters we get every few months. A title that injects a little humanity into an otherwise drab and faceless genre. Where your unwilling to make redshirts out of your pawns."

reviewText:
A great turn-based strategy game with RPG elements. There are many aspects I like about this game, including the combat mechanics; although the game can occasionally seem unfair (how could I miss with 80% hit chance?), it is actually a well-thought out system that works very well for the most part. I like how there are two different play modes - one is the on ground combat, and the other is managing your base. Think of the management aspect like a simplified Civ game. You are responsible for hiring scientists and engineers, building specific rooms, managing finances, hiring soldiers, deciding which soldiers to genetically modify, to name but a few. I also like the way each solider type (heavy, assault, support, and sniper) have their own tech trees. They are slightly limited, but enough to keep it interesting. The expansion adds plenty of content, such as new missions, weapons, and enemies.

Negatives are fairly minor. I feel there could have been more environment types (they get very stale after a while). Animations are sometimes a bit off, not enough to ruin the flow of the game, but they are noticeable. There is one enemy where their turn takes way too long, and can be irritating to wait for it to finish, especially when you are looking to load to a previous save.

Overall, a fantastic turn-based strategy game. Certainly one of my favourite stratey games. If you are late to the game like I was and enjoying good strategy, I recommend buying this ASAP.

reviewText:
Absolutely no regrets about dropping 60h of my life into this game - I'll probably be dropping 60h more into Enemy Within.

The mix of base management and squad based missions balances your stress levels.  Some missions really are tough and you  need a bit of a breather after completing them - especially losing a favourite soldier.

It takes time and effort to develop a good soldier, so losing him really is a crushing defeat!  This attachement to your individual soldiers is perhaps the aspect I enjoyed most about the game.  They aren't just replaceable cannon fodder - so you're focused on winning the mission AND on making sure they all survive.  This gets especially interesting on the terror missions - how much are you prepared to risk to save civilians?

reviewText:
XCOM EU is a Turn-Based Strategy, this is a sequel to the latest X-COM series, developed by Firaxis Games, the guys behind Sid Meier's Civilization

This game has long campaign and a good one, even on the hardest difficulty, its fun at time

Gameplay
For gameplay, it's like CIV. but it focuses more on turn-based ground combat uses an isometric 3D perspective. The player controls a squad of between one and six human soldiers or robotic units as they hunt the aliens on the map and attempt to complete other objectives dependent on the mission.

It has few frustrations like the enemy AI gets a free-move everytime your units meets up with them

Level Design
Map layouts are not randomly generated, but enemy placement is has a wide open area to move around and explore,

But at time enemies can shoot through walls, and sometimes your unit could not find the enemy behind the wall

Verdict
Overall, it's a good game, but it's full of frustration in-terms of AI, but if you're the type that can handle it

it has a sublime aesthetic of an alien apocalypse it has a undertone of a desperate last stand of humanity, that even though you are trying your hardest to repel the invaders they are so advanced and keep rolling out more and more horrors to kill you that it feels like you cannot prevail in the face of total destruction that is the alien threat.
You can of course as you examine the ETâ€™s technology and get stronger troops and equipment, the progression system in Xcom is fantastic because the aliens wonâ€™t wait for you to catch up if you are slow but wonâ€™t scale up if you do well. This means that you can excel in the field of blasting aliens (albeit only for a short while) and fell really good about yourself and is a awesome reward for doing well. You may want to (or have to) rage quit if your entire squad of super solders gets obliterated by something you went ready for (trust me it happens) but after you wail, gnash your teeth, cry for a solid ten minutes then play a more happy game while blubbering  and eating ice cream from the tub you will find yourself hitting that big PLAY XCOM button and getting right back into the game ready to shoot the crap out of all /insert baddy that killed the GI named after you/ at varied success depending on what that ET was and how tough they are.

reviewText:
As a former Mac user now Linux, I have come to love Feral Interactive. They are responsible for a vast amount of Mac ports, from Borderlands and Deus Ex: Human Revolution to Lego Batman and Worms 3D. The release of the Linux port of XCOM: Enemy Unknown is their first Linux release to date. Feral Interactive's Linux native port stands up well and plays smoothly at the highest settings. This is a very high-quality port and showcases the great work that Feral do. Expext more high quality Linux ports from them!


Now more about the game:
It's been years since I've played the original XCOM on my 386 computer, but I still vividly remember the hours of fun I had filing my team out of our landing craft to do battle with the alien hordes.

While my memory of the specifics of the classic XCOM are a bit hazy, I can tell you that all the major elements that I remember are fully intact in XCOM: Enemy Unknown (XEU). You get to do loads of research between missions, you can scramble jets to intercept UFOs and most of all, you get to send your team all over the world in turn-based combat with the aliens in your patient quest for new technology.

Despite the similarities to the original, it is immediately apparent that a lot of thought and polish went into the development of this new game.

--Your teammates can go up in rank as they gain more experience. Best of all, more experience means more abilities, but even this is not linear as you are often stuck with a choice of abilities, both almost equally tempting.

--Prepare to die a lot, but the Soldier Memorial adds a nice touch and encourages you to be more careful with your strategy to prevent further losses.

--Being able to view the anthill" of your base and excavate new areas gives you a great deal of satisfaction between missions.

--There are short load screens
date:
but they are integrated so well that you hardly even notice them (in particular the spacecraft cinematic when you fly to or from an engagement).

--Having people at headquarters that actually talk to you reminds me a bit of the advisors in the Civilization games.

--But perhaps some of my favorite things about XEU
recommended: are the global threat alerts and council meetings. Through both of these
hoursPlayed: you really feel like you are part of a global effort to defeat the aliens

So parents should have no problem with having their kids play this game if it is set up properly.\n\nIn an age where some developers seem to favor style over substance

reviewText:
I've spent a lot of time on this game, and I keep coming back to it. It's a challenging, engaging game, no doubt about it. It's easy to get hyped up on XCOM 2 (ETA: less than a month as of review), but this game has charm. Sure, stuff like forced failure in the form of abductions and unusual glitches mean the game isn't perfect. But no game is.

It's hard to describe the feeling I get from playing XCOM, because it is like no other game I've played. It's not forgiving. RNG will get in the way every day. Your soldiers will die. You will cry. But you will get up, and try again. You will get better, and try again. And you will strike at increasingly higher difficulties, hopefully achieving the venerable I/I run. The fact that this game pulls no punches means that every action, every death, and most of all, every victory, means something.

They've digged up an old game from the grave. That means there's changes from the good old UFO days. People that liked the old UFO games may not like this one. It definitely changes a lot. There's no more TUs. Inventories are streamlined. You can only have one base.

But I played the old UFO, and I loved it to bits. I played this reboot, and I loved it to bits. So it's not correct to say that nobody who played the UFO games will like this one, because I did. For old veterans of the franchise and newcomers alike, I must wholeheartedly recommend.

reviewText:
There's a reason why this game is a top seller. game of the year, and on my favorites. I rate games on several factors: music, sound effects, graphics/art style, game play, difficulty options, learning, replayability, stakes, and story/dialogue. I then weigh that to the price of the game.

The story is so compelling and something I absolutely love. Earth is under alien invasion. In order to face the threat, the forces of Earth ally. There's many places that need help, and you cannot pick all of them. Hopefully you can gather knowledge to further your tech to aid in the war. I love how the US works with China and Russia and other countries.

The music of Mass Effect reminds me of the music from XCOM. That's one reason why I liked Mass Effect and why I LOVE XCOM. This ties into the stakes. The stakes are high! Alien invasion. There's only one planet. And the music expresses how this is a war for survival. And I felt it. No matter what there will be casualties.

Stakes ties into the story and difficulty. The planet is under attack! And if you choose the ironman difficulty. If someone dies, they're dead. So every choice you make matters, and may or may not result in a injured or killed squadmate. Or a failed mission.

There's a lot of learning in this game. I've played it on Ironman. And I have started the game over, a dozen or so times.

The graphics didn't blow me away. But the art choices did. The lighted lines of the alien canisters to the look of a sectoid or muton. The color pallete of a soft blue with black and white gives a futuristic vibe. And the UI is quite intuitive. There's personality! The skyhawk has a no sectoid paint on it.

Gameplay is where the game really shines! I love tactical strategy based games. Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, Shining Force, Shadowrun, etc. And this game has it. Combat will take a long time. Each movement will be calculated. Is there enough cover? Can I flank without getting flanked? How much will moving to this spot increase/decrase my to hit %?

Replayability. The game has it. You can beat it one way, maybe following a specific strategy or losing a few council members. Or you can make an attempt at not losing any members or only using a specific class. I've played this game so much and everyone I've told about it has loved it. I'm sure you will too!

reviewText:
Assassinâ€™s Creed II, Batman: Arkham City, Borderlands 2. Never would I envision another game would barge in and join this prestigious list of games. Out of nowhere, comes XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a turn based tactical warfare game where you command a squad of soldiers against aliens (classic). Expectations are set for you as commander to save human civilization and rid of the invading species. Right at the start, the game flung you into the mix of things with a steep learning curve. On the commanding side, you have to maintain panic levels that keep your ally countries to fund your XCOM project which is your main source of income. If you fail, they leave the XCOM project forever and you get zero funding from them onwards. The income is used to upgrade your base, weapons, and other perks. On the battlefield, keeping your squad members alive is crucial. The game runs on perma-death. If a squad member dies, he dies for good. After that, he can only be selected in the memorial and you can lookup on which mission he perished. Of course you can hire a new soldier but losing your best soldier on the field doesnâ€™t feel good right. During combat, the way you inflict damage to your opponents is percentage based and relies heavily on positioning as well as flanking. Ever missed a 98%  point blank shot? Hell yeah. But when you hit that crucial 9% shot that saves your team from total annihilation. A sigh of relief. You will never have the calmness to expand your base as the game throws problems one after another at you. The brutal yet realistic nature of the game brings a satisfying gaming experience.

As mentioned, the game excels in turn based combat. It is realistic as it does not provide you an easy way out of sticky situations. An easy mission can be brutally difficult if patience is not taken into consideration. Charging into a swarm of enemies almost guarantees a death or two. What makes this game better is soldiers having distinct classes when ranking up. Each class will have their own skill tree. With each soldiersâ€™ rank up, a skill can be selected between two choices to specialize the unit. You can choose having higher defense to soak up damage for your allies as a vanguard or increased critical chance while close up to the enemy to be that devastating spearhead your team desperately needs. Your team composition is solely up to you. Moreover, the underlying tension when in base or out in the field on uncertainties of what will happen next will keep you on your toes. Iâ€™ve spent hours in the game calculating my every movement, in which I thought I only spent minutes. This just signifies how immersive this game truly is. However, XCOM Enemy Unknown has its fair share of problems. The first noticeable flaw is graphical glitches. I saw my Japanese sniper nicknamed â€˜Headshotâ€™ charge up his plasma rifle to land a headshot while the plasma beam pierces through a friendly unit, a car, a wall AND then the alienâ€™s head. In addition, switching elevation level in the game can be frustrating at times as layers of flooring are hard to navigate properly. The second issue is the random map generator. There is a limited pool of maps that is chosen for each mission and when you play a lot, you start to notice maps reoccurring, just from different angles where you start the mission from. The suburbs of USA look exactly the same as the that from India. Nevertheless, these imperfections donâ€™t create much of an issue for an extremely flawless game, literally at 98%. With XCOM 2 just out, I might just be seduced into purchasing it seeing how good the prequel, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is.

Pros:
- In depth turn based tactical combat
- Realistic and unforgiving in nature
- Customizable and personalized team composition with plentiful options
- Tension loaded experience

Cons:
- Constant graphical glitches
- Repeating maps used for missions in different parts of the world

Rating: 9.8/10
(What? Iâ€™m obsessed with 9 and 8 together in this game, 98% sure)

reviewText:
I came to XCOM a little late--after all my friends had played and recommended it, I knew I wouldn't dislike the game. I'm glad I gave it a chance because this is one of the few single-player games I've finished and thouroughly enjoyed.

This game is definitely about adaptation; you must constantly be aware of positioning, how skills interplay with one another, and learning (painfully) what does and doesn't work against certain alien types.

The story isn't terribly engrossing. You progress through the story by researching alien technology and integrating it into your own arsenal. What makes it so much fun is naming all the characters after your friends, and then trying like hell not to get them killed. Thank god for the save/reload function, as I used it far more often than I probably should have.

I enjoy turn-based games, and this one doesn't have a ridiculously high learning curve--anyone can play on normal and with some basic trial-and-error, figure out a way to beat the game. However, the one thing I didn't understand at the beginning, and wish I would have known earlier on is: BUILD SATTELITES. BUILD UPLINKS. Finished? BUILD SOME MORE.

If you enjoy tactical, turn-based games, and you haven't given XCOM a try, I highly recommended it. Blow up a few friends, it's great fun.

i had been searching for a game for the past 5 years  that had really good Team based Turn Strategy/Role play, coming from Riviera The Promised land, Yddgra union, Fire Emblem (pre-game Cube), Rebel Star, Tactics Ogre, Final Fantasy Tactics, i knew from the first day Xcom came to steam, this would be my game!. reviewText: Before I even started playing XCOM: Enemy Unknown I was sceptical, as not many developers out there can produce a masterpiece when it comes to turn-based strategies... reviewText:
Quite an engaging little game, this is.

As a first-time XCOM player, I must say that Enemy Unknown is one of the better turn-based games I've played in a while. I spent a great deal of time hoarding my resources and hiding within my labs in order to obtain the most high-tech weapons, just because I tend to get rather attached to my troops; having to gun down your most powerful commando after he's been zombified by a Chryssalid is a disturbing prospect. Even with the game getting disappointingly simple and trivial once you've got your entire squad at maximum rank with the best skills, the biggest weapons and the highest psi (the only squad deaths coming from my own carelessness or from a completely unacceptable critical kill), XCOM: Enemy Unknown is definitely something I enjoy playing and supporting. Currently on my eighth game with no plans of stopping for good coming anytime soon.

P.S: XCOM: Enemy Within makes the whole experience even better, by the way. Get it!

reviewText:
Xcom enemy unknown/ Enemy within
i had been searching for a game for the past 5 years  that had really good Team based Turn Strategy/Role play, coming from Riviera The Promised land, Yddgra union, Fire Emblem (pre-game Cube), Rebel Star, Tactics Ogre, Final Fantasy Tactics, i knew from the first day Xcom came to steam, this would be my game!. A game that has Role play value through character creation and Story  is a real seller for me, along with tight Controls and minimal glitches and pretty much well thought out mechanics.
The game has squad based Tactics, research to upgrade your units, recruitment drives, Science research to integrate alien tech into your Project, Increasing difficulty, random events, DLC that expands on all this, along side Alien variaton, a TON of maps, and Almost full customizability of each character you recruit, these options are  hair, Armour, faces,colors, helmets, and Voice nationality.

Does it have replayability? yes sir, with features like Second wave and Classic/Ironman modes yes sir or madam it does!
THese help vary your troops on how they grow, the abilities they get, and provide extra challenges and or advantages, along side to adding Handi caps to aliens and or making it so you cannot save or reload, what you get is what you get, you fail, you cannot reload.

But thats all the good, how about the Bad?****

1. Sometimes, (RARE) The camera gets stuck and it cannot be moved or no actions can be done, you must re-load your save (in ironman mode you cant do this)

2. 1 or 2 enemies in a full play through will Teleport from beyond the map into the Dark (glitch) then respawn infront of you the next turn.

3. I think its a current problem, but Bio electric skin should only be put onto 1 character for it to work fully, having more than 1 person in the squad with bio-electric skin will need you to have the whole squad to be within 2 squares of each other for the ability to work for 1 character.

***** 1 and 2 only happend to me once in 3 play throughs of the game, its safe to say its really rare

This game is a must buy with the DLC if you are into Turn based Strategies, fully replayable, and into Alien Devastation, this game really does make you feel almost powerless against the aliens...but only you can make the diffrence between winning it for human kind, or loosing it...

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown is still one of my favourite games of all time. Sure, it is turn-based combat and if you really tried, you can find a few faults with it, but the gameplay is tight, fun, brings across the combat from what I know of the original xcom very well and is very engaging and rewarding.

You play as the commander of the XCOM project. An organisation built to defend earth from the encroaching threat of alien invasion. In the base you arrange for a whole host of things to happen; You sort out your soldiers (hiring, dismissing, equipping, promoting, skill selection, customisation etc), your research projects to get better stuff, interrogations of captives, your base expansions, building and improving of equipment, taking requests from other Countries, selling alien objects, sending up satelites etc etc. So basically, you do lots of stuff. It's deep, engaging and you honestly do end up getting absorbed in everything which all ties up nicely and affects your soldiers in the field.

The field operations are turn based assaults, rescues, area securing and other various missions (depending on dlc or not) which take place in different areas which you do get to see a few times, but are infrequent enough and varied enough to still be interesting. The aliens you fight are nicely varied and gradually get more difficult as the game progresses and the whole thing has a nice tie-in with the base gameplay. You capture aliens, alloys, meld (dlc) and sometimes even soldier units in the field, then use those in the base to make more stuff, which then helps in the field next time. It's smooth, intuitive and really engaging.

There are flaws, naturally. Sometimes some of the abilities seem a little abstracted from the map geometry and units can sometimes see or even shoot through walls at times. The randomness of the ways you can get resources can be a limitation if you're out of funds for this month and seriously need to start building more stuff, but it does not affect gameplay negatively to a huge extent.

Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a fantastic game, with a good story, immersive gameplay and great mechanics. It is fun and interesting, which in my book, is a big plus these days!

reviewText:
1-sentence review for the solo game : slightly simplified version of the 1994 classic, X-Com (with its indispensable Enemy Within DLC) is a great game with a fabulous atmosphere, even if it's lacking of strategy depth, with the RNG having too much importance, and could have used a more diversified campaign to increase its replayability.

Pros:Awesome alien invasion ambiance
Easy to get into
Your soldiers almost never gets one-shot killed (unlike 1994 version), and later on you have options to make them even more resistant ; so most of times, your soldiers will die from your mistakes, not from bad luck
Solid basis for the tactical combats (but see the cons...)
Environment is partly destructible, and it really matters (ie: for the Line of Sights)
Cons:Random Number Generator (RNG) is still too important ; missing 4 70-80% shots in a row will happen sometimes (which is statically logical) and can lead to a squad wipe
The more you lose, the more you lose ; coupled with the RNG issue, it means your campaign can go to waste even if you don't do any serious mistake
Story & Story-telling are nothing special
Seriously lacks of tactical depth : once you know how to move & position your soldiers, you'll just have to know how to chain a few actions and you'll be all set and do the same things over and over again
This means the combats also lack of variation : it's more or less the same during the entire course of the game (but the base mechanics are good, so we can't complain too much ;) )
With only 1 base, and not much pro-active choices on our part, the campaign plays out almost identically from 1 run to the next one ; ie: we're on a rail, seeing almost always the same things, only sometimes not in the same order
There are some little bugs & glitches ; eg: using the grapple can teleport you on the other side of the map >_<

reviewText: I first encountered xcom as a demo on xbox360. I also used to be a person who did not like the idea of turn based strategy games. Then I tried xcom, and fell in love with this game so much that when I got a computer I bought it on Steam too. What makes this game so good in my opinion? This game takes time to learn. You will make mistakes and lose. When you do not allow yourself to make the same mistakes and learn from them, the more you play, the better you will get. What I like most about xcom is the fact that when I first started this game, I was clueless. This is my first turn based strategy game. As I continued to play xcom, I became better and was able to finally beat classic difficulty with ironman mode enabled. This game requires you to make hard choices that are not always clear. That is why I like this game so much. It requires you to think about every choice you make in the base management side, and in the turn based tactical combat side. Every choice you make in base management has an upside and downside. The combat layer also has hard choices as well, requiring you to adapt and have backup plans, should your initial plan fail. Trust me, you will learn to hate this game and love it at the same time. The tutorial does a nice job of teaching you the basics, but it does not teach you some of the more unorthodox strategies that you have to learn on your own, or learn it from other players. Even though this game does have some bug issues from time to time, the main reason you will learn to like this game is simple. It will never be exactly the same twice. EVER. My main advice to new players or first time players of xcom, is to take your time. Patience and planning ahead will always be your most deadly weapon in this game. I hope that anyone reading this can give this game a chance as I did. I can honestly say that I do not regret playing this game one bit. If you like turn based strategy games, this game will give you a run for your money.

reviewText:
The aliens have invaded Earth and XCOM, a secret project created by the Council of Nations, becomes our planet's last line of defense. As its commander, you will have to manage everything, from research, recruitment, building projects and deciding where to intervene in the world against the invaders.

I never played a previous XCOM before, so that shouldn't be a problem if you haven't either. On the other hand, I must warn you that this game is very hard and pretty unforgiving. Getting your team completely wiped out for a little tactical mistake is a common thing.

There is also an ironman mode, where everything you do is irreversible, giving it a rogue-like experience, plus with the permanent death of your squad members and excellent soundtrack, the grid turn based battles can get pretty tense.

In the end, XCOM is a serious candidate for game of the year! Everything in it is great, from the tactical and engaging battles, to the base management and world affairs and the difficult decisions it presents to you. A must buy!

reviewText:
Before I had played XCOM, I always thought it was a rogue-lite that lasts 10+ hours before you fail. The difficulty of XCOM had always dissuaded me from trying, which I think more people would love the game if they knew the challenge can be manageable.

However, and this is said after I've finished a 19-hr Normal game and tried 15-hr of Classic Mode (with modifiers like ironman), I don't always think the game is fair with its difficulty. It can be very unfair with broken mechanics,  UI/camera problems and a steep difficulty spike from Normal to Classic.

I won't say the unfairness ruins the game because I want the challenge, but they are all issues. My ideal solution of a difficulty is one that has the AI behavior of Classic but the leeway you have in Normal mode. (Something I've heard is possible with the Long War mod.)

An Important Note
I do own the complete edition of XCOM, so while I have Enemy Within I have not played it.  I wanted to evaluate the merits of Enemy Unknown (around 30 hrs) before I evaluated what EW adds to EU.

Also, one note about the cosmetics'/council-missions DLC: Buy them ONLY if you care for customizing your characters but do not buy them individually (either buy the base-game or complete pack).

What the Game Does Right
What Firaxis does considerably well is provide a more streamlined, accessible game for a hardcore niche title. I have tried XCOM: UFO Defense long ago, so I have experienced what the old games demanded of the player.

So while I see how the base management, item-inventory and squad-sizes are less demanding, I think the game's focus on squad-tactics, resource-management and the action of XCOM makes for a fun game in its own right.

The best way I can describe the game is that it's a Civilization's take on XCOM. (Barren on plot, heavy on gameplay and the personal-stories you can have from the gameplay.)

To my surprise, there is a considerable variety of missions--though you'll mostly get three: Exterminate, Extract and Escort--when you include the randomized council missions to keep the game refressing even after 15+ hours.

Normal (Recommended) vs. Classic
If you are new to XCOM, I would suggest you begin at nothing lower than Normal (with saves). After your first win, you should enable no saves to keep yourself from reloading every turn. (i.e. Reloading for maximizing probabilities.)

The only worry you have in Normal is of overpowering yourself if you prioritize the base-management/squad-upgrades. You can easily take away the tension. The early-game difficulty returns after the alien base-assault when the game brings its heavier units.

Easing yourself into EU is not the only reason to start at Normal. You should have no problem managing finances for the base and squad-upgrades, so you'll also learn what to prioritize. You'll also learn which autopsies and interrogations give you bonus research points" for other research. (The research is very similar to Civ 5
date: except with required materials for study.)\n\nBasically
recommended: the normal mode is to familiarize yourself with the mechanics and the game's glossary of enemies
hoursPlayed: the armory
voteText: and bonuses.\n\nClassic Mode is where most would say the true game is found. Enemy behaviors are greatly improved--Thin Men spit acid

votesHelpful: etc.--and the early enemies are more threatening rather than being forgotten. (Like the Outsider.)\n\nYou will fail if you start in Classic
votesTotal: and even after familiarizing yourself on Normal you probably won't reach the Alien Base assault for a while. Even with many of the Second Wave modifiers for difficulty

every time you spot an enemy they get to scatter freely and then attack you at the end of your turn. (Sometimes the enemy will sit still and you must trigger them.) The best solution is to either scout ahead with someone ghosted or use trackers to spot them from afar and hunker down.

I don't have an issue with constant the two-second cinematic. What I do have a problem is how your units do not react similarly to spotting an enemy.

Another related issue is Overwatch. Because of the isometric camera

An XCOMplimishment Despite its Flaws
What I think EU succeeds in is providing a unique experience where you develop a love-hate honeymoon.

It begins all tender and carefree until those damning issues make you want to quit or to give up. In spite of those issues
column31: they never keep you from trying over and over again. thinking
column32: "Some day I can look over all failures by accomplishing this one thing. It will be the one thing I've done right." Then
column33: nine-months later you find that there's a Sectoid baby. You  dispose of it
column34:
and you are left pondering where did you go wrong and what to do about it now.

Then you start it all over again. (Just like Cpt. Kirk would want to be remembered.)

reviewText:
In XCOM: Enemy Unknown players are tasked with running a military base who's sole purpose is to defend the Earth from alien attacks. The base view is presented in an ant farm style, which allows you to explore the structure of your base as though it is a living system. Unfortunately in this iteration of XCOM satellite uplinks/nexus are so vital to your success (especially on harder difficulties) that you are forced into a fairly standard base makeup. If you don't focus on getting your satellites up, you will almost certainly lose.

The main focus of the game is the battles, which on the whole are interesting and tense. Cover is vital during tactical battles, and if you do not use appropriate cover on harder difficulties you will quickly lose your valuable soldiers as often times taking one hit means death. Forcing yourself to use Iron Man difficulty or otherwise not reloading your saves is almost certainly the most interesting to play the game and means that losing a soldier is permanent. But it's this chance of permanent loss that brings so much tension and excitement to the battles. There is nothing like the joy of nailing an alien on a 25% chance shot and save a squad member's life, or the sting that comes from missing a 97% shot you thought for sure was in the bag. Soldiers rank up from battles and learn more and more abilities as they do. Successfully completing missions and killing aliens you can recover their technology in order to research it and further improve your soldiers. The visual upgrades your soldiers get from new equipment is probably one of the most appealing aspects of the game. Seeing a loved soldier move up from standard gear to become a future soldier with glowing guns and sleek armor is fantastic.

Unfortunately in the battles the AI opponents do not follow the same rules as the player units until they are 'activated' by coming into field of view of your soldiers. Until they activate they are essentailly one 'unit' and will teleport around the battlefield (outside of your view usually) into positions of varying believability. For instance one time I cleared a building by killing all the sectoids within, and then my soliders heard a sound coming from the neighbouring building. As I stacked my soldiers up on the doors and prepared to breach the building they suddenly heard sounds behind them. I sent them back to the first building only to find more sectoids had teleported onto the ones that I just killed, and were no longer in the building my soldiers heard them in only two turns ago. Another case of this is when my rookie soldiers began to panic and hunker down, I once had a group of sectoids teleport in the middle of my soliders! They quickly took cover on every side of my soldiers and were flanking from so many angles that there was no chance success at all.

Another way in which the game 'cheats' is during some missions (usually 'council' missions like escorting VIPs or defusing bombs) aliens will simply drop in from the sky. They'll either drop in out of view, behind you, in perfect sniping positions, at your flank, at all of your flanks... in other words, pretty much anywhere. There is a pattern to when they drop in, but there is no warning, or rather the warning comes as they are dropping on top of you which kind of renders it useless.

While there are certainly some problems and questionable decisions in this reboot, overall it is a very worthy successor to the original. XCOM: Enemy Unknown kind of screws up the base building by railroading you into satellite focus, and the tactical battles by cheating the rules your soldiers are forced to follow. On the other hand they enhance the experience by allowing your soldiers to learn interesting abilities when they rank up, including some interesting equipment and enemy types, and just making the game much shinier and easier to play.

Overall it is clearly one of the most solid strategy games on Steam despite it's flaws. It is one of my favourites in my collection and I'm sure that will only be reinforced by Enemy Within.

reviewText:
In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, the earth is gradually coming under attack from extraterrestrials seeking to kill us all. As the head of the XCOM project, a secret organization funded by nations throughout the world to fight the aliens, you manage your squad of soldiers on the ground in turn based tactics, the direction of your research labs (better armor or better weapons?), and even general base-building (Should I go with more research labs or a power generator?). Decisions, decisons.

As time goes by, the aliens will step up their offense, sending down a variety of aliens from the dreaded tank-like mutons to the spider-like zombie spawning Chryssalid. But shall you prioritize the correct research, you'll get better weapons to combat the ever-growing threat.

The combat in the game as I mentioned, is turn-based tactical, as you control a squad of 4 (at the start) performing a search/destroy mission. You soldiers level up as they perform missions and kill aliens. They can be promoted into one of 4 classes namely Assault, Support, Heavy, and Sniper. Each with their special abilities. As your men level up, you'll begin to feel for your men, each with their own unique nicknames. You could even rename them in to your friends if you like! But be careful though, if you don't get your men into cover, they will die. Alot. XCOM is an unforgiving game where emphasis is based on being aware of your surroundings and efficiently using cover.

The game is best played on Ironman mode where the game overwrites your save file with each turn you make, so if you lose your colonel, well, you can't go back in time to reverse that poor decision you made. The game is made by Firaxis, makers of Civilization series, so you can expect a top notch quality game.

5/5 GOTY 2012

Edit: It's even better if you could get the expansion for the game, XCOM: Enemy Within. Just released a month ago, it features a whole new variety of maps (so you won't replay the same map for the upteenth time.), more enhancements for your men featuring the power-fist wielding mech suit (to punch those darn aliens!), genetic mods for your men to become something like Captain America! And a whole new enemy faction; Exalt. These buggers want to use alien tech for world domination, akin to an evil version of XCOM. They can sabotage your base, steal your credits etc. But you can take them out later in the game.

XCOM Enemy Within also mixes it up with a whole new alien resource to collect when on the ground; meld. They can be used for gene mods and building mech suits for your men. But be careful though. These things self-destruct after a certain number of turns, thus mixing up the combat! RIsk = Reward baby!

XCOM ENEMY WITHIN is highly recommended for enhancing your XCOM experience! It's easily one of the best DLCs out there this past year. 5/5

As usual XCOM is not for the faint hearted. Missed that 95% chance shot with your sniper, and getting your men killed the next turn? That's XCOM BABY! Have fun Commander!

reviewText:
The brief explanation is that this game was a painful oversimplification of everything Xcom was supposed to be.

The missions were dumbed down into linear tasks where new enemies are literally spawned in front of you once you kill all the ones that were already on the ground.  The combat has been turned even more into a case of rolling random numbers like a tabletop RPG, roll a high enough number and bullets can go around corners, rendering cover into a simple stat modifier instead of a physical object.

If you're a fan of the original, check out a game like UFO Afterlight instead.  It's a knockoff of the original Xcom, but if anything it deserves the name of Xcom far more than this superficial reboot does.

reviewText:
This game is beautiful.  It has a dramatic soundtrack and solid voice acting.  The base design and combat mechanics are wonderful ... with a few soul-crushing game-killing flaws.

tl;dr, I'm glad this game was gifted to me.  I can't force myself to finish it or buy the expansions.

--The two action points are a grand improvement over the original x-com ... but restricting their use in any way was a mistake.  What if I want to fire first and then move or reload?
--The AI mobs should NOT get a free movement the moment you spot them.
--Why the hell can't I build more than one actual base and/or develop enough teams to respond to more than one terror attack at a time?  You're pitting me against arbitrary mechanics, not my ability to fight aliens.
--All equipment held by an alien explodes if the wielder of that equipment dies ... are you kidding?  You know, you could've just adjusted the economy to account for me picking apart all the stuff the AI's drop and it wouldn't have felt like you were intentionally screwing me here.
-- Why can't I specify what class of trooper I'd like to recruit?  The class system is cool, but it's crippling to have to fight a few battles with a guy only to find out he randomly rolled a class I do not need at the moment and be forced to give him the boot.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game. This is after having beaten Classic Ironman, too.

As much as I'd like to enjoy it - and my god with the way everything is presented and the theoretical fun that you could have, I sure want to... but I simply cannot.

Play through the game on normal difficulty, and you'll find that the game is way too easy. Step it up to classic, and throw in ironman too to make this game into somewhat of a challenge (and arguably the way it should be - with ironman) and you'll find yourself consistently fighting against AI which it feels like is constantly cheating.

LoS is garbage in this game, your units behind even full cover will regularly get devastated by the aim bonus given to aliens on higher difficulties (I must reiterate that anything below classic is easy as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥) while you find yourself unable to land a single shot, and the way enemies spawn in packs is probably one of the most idiotic things I've ever seen.

The enemy gets free bonuses to make up for â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ AI and adds what could actually be called artifical difficulty, LoS is broken as all hell, and the way in which enemies spawn FORCES a playstyle in which you take a half step forward and then proceed to try and bait aliens backwards into your overwatched squad - which is not only stupid and repetitive, it's down right bad game design.

I'm rather disgusted I paid full price for this piece of trash. Buy Xenonauts instead for a much better experience in which the AI beats you through smart play, not cheating. Alternatively, Frozen Synapse if you're looking for turn based multiplayer.

reviewText:
For me as an X-Com: Enemy Unknown/UFO Defense veteran, this game is comparably easy to manage and the combat system is easier to learn. However, even if tactical parts are stripped down to a certain extent, this remake isn't anymore a simple remake. It's a remaster or a reboot; it has a rather good story line, it adds tons of gameplay features to consider being really good design choices, it got rid of bothering features like the air combat system (which had an awesome music track in the original nonetheless) and of course it has considerable visual/audio overhauls. This game stays true to its root(s) in a degree that it indeed is comparable to the original game (which is a really rare achievement for reboots) but, in my opinion, blows it away with so many additions that it beats the classic masterpiece. This game sets a new standard for this genre.

Veterans, if you think it's too easy for you and I'd see where you'd be coming from; it offers many options to increase it's difficulty. If it's just to set the difficulty higher as a whole or to enable the Iron Man mode, where you play it a lot more like a rogue-lite (permadeath, auto-saving-only) or maybe enabling more randomness. You pay a bit freedom in this game (freedom of base locations i.e.), but you get so much more.

I highly recommend this game to anyone slightly interested in TB-Combat.

reviewText: Think strategically or die. That is the motto you live by in this awesome reboot of the long ignored but never faded title. After your first fight you get to head back to base and begin customizing soldiers the way you want, even so they are named after and resemble your friends and family, giving you just that much more investment in their continued survival. But soon the fights become more intense with choosing between moving your characters to better positions or taking the risk to stand your ground and fight. The enemies you face get progressively harder as you advance through the story (unless you're on a harder difficulty then then they get harder no matter how much you've progressed) and all of them have different ways of fighting you off. The tension is always up to 10 and goes to 11 on those times where you're outnumbered, outgunned and running low on medikits. Even if you make it back to base the tension does not let up. Different countries start to panic and threaten to leave the council that fund your operations. You live or die on the choices you make on a shoe-string budget. You even begin to sell off important assets just to make it a few more days. This game is concentrated intensity and it will have you biting your nails and praying for just one more well-placed shot/credit/day/less panic bar/engineer/scientist/mission/movement tile/round all the way into the wee hours of the morning. Buy this game and don't bother looking back.

reviewText:
Xcom came to my library in the strangest way... I was in the Warhammer 40k: Chaos Gate remake forum in the community when someone said XCOM had similarities with CG, at first i didnt put a lot of attention to it, but later in the infamous summer sale (Thank you Steam...sarcasm btw i saw a great discount and took the opportunity to research the ame a little bit...

Now i have been playing it like theres no tomorrow, its a real delight for turn based strategy lovers like myself, heres my humble view on the good stuff and the annoying stuff:

Good Stuff
- Good Graphics and scenery
- Gameplay is simple and fluid
- AI is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ sometimes...yes a good stuff
- The HQ management and item progression has a lot of variety
- Customization for Squads is awesome as well as the promotion scale
- Lots of sidemissions and you choose when to continue the main campaign
- The money management needs some thinking, otherwise you can bankrupt the xcom project
- Camera rotation, angles and voice acting is great

Not so good stuff...more like annoying

Frankly there are no such things i considered bad, more like annoying details:
- Soldiers can panic and sometimes while they are scared they shoot friends
- Personally i would prefer more story background of the beginning of the alien invasion...maybe xcom the bureau: declassified has it, i dont know
- Sometimes a % of a success shot its not accurate with the reality of covered enemies or own squad
- Saving and loading needs a simpler method...come on its a turn based game...basic.

Overall its a terrific game, if i had known about it earlier i would be replaying it at this moment, highly addictive and frustrating too, which is a good thing...sometimes when in a single turn the enemy crushes you and the last saving point is 3 missions back..its just lovely

reviewText: Keeping this short and sweet, I think that XCOM: Enemy Unknown (with OR without Enemy Within) is one of the best strategy games in years. As good as games like Total War and StarCraft are, turn-based strategy with a small squad was always my preference, because what actions you take feel like personal choices, making every single decision you make on and off the battlefield a tough one. And BOY, do they get tough. If you have paitence to loose time and time again, then an experience on the rewarding levels of Dark Souls awaits you. XCOM reminds me a lot of games like Fire Emblem, Advance Wars, or Tactics Orge, but it sprinkles some western elements into it as well as some sci-fi giving it a unique identity of its own. Overall, this game ends up culminating into a big pile of difficult, stratigec, rewarding fun. And honestly? I wouldn't have it any other way.

reviewText: This is a remake of the popular XCOM game in the 90's. Although I was not able to actually play that game and was only able to watch videos of it over the internet, I still see how a good game it was before. You will feel tension with the different member countries of the council due to the politics it entails as they ask for assistance with these invasions. One wrong decision may spell the end for your squad member and you can never bring him back. This is the epitome of strategy. You will never be successful without thinking everything through. reviewText:
A must buy re-imagining of the classic XCOM: UFO Defense (US) and UFO: Enemy Unknown (UK/EU) from the 90s; this edition has the unusual distinction of taking a classic, reimagining it and possibly making it a better game.

Run the worldwide anti-alien response team by building bases, shooting down UFOs and command gun battles on the ground. The game has a strong story with a good research tree that keeps the challenge real. The DLC is worth having with the Enemy Within adding a bundle of interesting content.

The only flaw with the game is that the 'on the ground' battle sections can get a bit repetitive if you aren't testing new toys your scientists have dreamed up in the field, but overall the combat is much more enjoyable than previous incarnations by seriously reducing the amount of micromanagement.

I wouldn't recommend buying it with The Bureau which was a more poorly received console shooter which is only worth buying with 90% off.

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn-Based Strategy game centering on squad-level tactics. You are in command of XCOM, an organization devoted to fighting off the threat of alien invaders. Your mission is to protect the Earth from this invasion, stopping alien abductions, terror attacks on population centers, and otherwise keeping everyone from panicking and defunding your project, gradually accumulating superior weapons and technology from the aliens so that you have a fighting chance.


Overall, the game is quite strong; the macro-level stuff is fairly addictive in its skinner-box techniques as there is always something new which is going to come just around the corner, and the combat-level stuff works well enough, though it is not perfect either. On the whole, it really makes you want to play through the whole game, though at the very end of the game it may end up feeling a bit strange; there comes a point at which you are really in control of the situation and the earlier desperation goes away, and about that same point the research starts really drying up, meaning that if you take too long to finish the game, it could potentially get a bit dry; the last couple missions before I beat the game were the weakest in the game simply because I had figured it out and there was little threat from the game at that point.

Still, I played through and beat the game in three or four sittings, which is always a sign that a game has you hooked.

reviewText:
First off I'm not a fan of turn-based games but XCOM really blew my mind.
The gameplay is just so well made with it's cover system, the weapons and what damage they do to the environment and how you feel connected to your soldiers.
As each soldier has their own nationality, facial features and names (facial features and names can be changed) it makes every single one stand out and sometimes you'll do anything to keep them alive. There's also an option that prevents you to save during missions which will make you think twice about what move you're going to make as every single mistake can change everything during a mission.
There's 5 classes (6 in enemy within) all with their own very important roles. Each time they level you get to choose a perk in their skill tree, normally each class has their set perks to choose from but there's an option that makes the perks random so you could end up with a soldier that has a perfect set of perks from different classes.
XCOM also offers the ability to build up your own base, do research and create items and weapons and it's more or less up to you in what order you want to do things.

The Enemy Within expansion gives you a new class, a heavy cyborg/mech kind of class aswell as implants for regular soldiers that will boost them quite alot.

The missions in The Enemy Within are the same as in Enemy Unknown so if you think you'll only be playing the game once I would really recommend getting the expansion right away as it offers alot more options to your playthrough.

Even if you're normally not a turn-based gamer I would recommend trying this game, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
It's funny. Most reboots/reimaginings/rediscoveries leave you with a bitter taste in your mouth.

Ok it's not funny. It's disappointing. And bitter.

The results of years of anticipation & longing, fear of letting down a frothing fanbase that crushes creativity & publishers rushing games out the door I suppose.

But anyways, that doesn't exist here. The bitter taste that is.

This reimagining seems to capture the spirit of whatever it is that made the original set of xcoms great whilst still dressing it in a way to appeal to the unwashed masses.

The low level tactical game which is I propose the meat of xcom is perhaps better than the originals. They've done away with a lot of the tedious micromanagement such as dragging ammo into or out of each of your soldiers. They've streamlined & simplified things & yet somehow still managed to retain enough so that it doesn't feel as if it's been dumbed down. You're left with nail biting decisions such as should i rush forward to finish off this alien & risk exposing new aliens"? Or "should i take that 40% shot or cower in cover?".

The high level strategic game however leads a bit to be desired. There's only 1 base. & everything just feels a little bit boring once you've worked things out. I liked the way apocalypse headed with all the crazy levels of details in the city layer & this seems like a fair step backwards.

Anywayz

reviewText:
An overall qualifier for this recommendation: Squad and base-building games are something I adore, and this rather skews my predisposition to XCOM towards the positive.

That said, it's one of the finest examples of these genres and turn-based combat and tactics games in general that's out there, in my opinion.  Your squad is deep and varied, tech and research provides gear that changes up your options and approaches, and the presentation and story are done in a compelling and involving way; it's not hard for me to develop attachments to my individual soldiers, especially with campaign options that allow each to have a unique skill tree.

All of the things I like about this game are further enhanced by the Long War mod for it-- more equipment, more challenge, more character builds with more compelling and balanced options, and more varied technology to uncover.  If you're a fan of base building strategy and turn-based tactics, this one deserves a look-- buy it with Enemy Within, its fully featured expansion pack that greatly improves the campaign experience and lets you train psychic humans using alien tech, among other things.  Defend Earth.  Purge xenos.  Good times.

My most recent game is telling the great tale of an Irish solider known as Private First Class Bryan Murphy. He seems to be quite remarkable in the sense that he misses all his 40% - 90% shots and I can only assume that this is because he is a financially deprived alcoholic who left his kids to join XCOM and is too drunk to shoot. Although he makes incredible game changing 10%-20% chance to hit shots all the time. Needless to say, I warmed to him immediately and I literally think he has a hidden 'luck of the irish' perk or a four leaf clover stowed away somewhere.

Bryan Murphy is the only reason I am continuing to play my current playthrough and that is because of his rather magical ability to save soldiers he considers more important than him. However this is not the case. For this reason I am seriously considering spending vast amount of XCOM savings to put Bryan Murphy through officer's school. Hopefully this would boost his self esteem long enough for him to agree to a rehab program I have set up in base to help recovering substance abusers better themselves.  As a commander I am seriously concerned for his well being.

Come christmas time, I always give my soldiers a christmas bonus to raise their morale. I even take days off when the alien threat is minimal to go out and help my troops buy quality presents at excellent prices. Due to Bryan Murphy's drinking habits I personally took the liberty of visiting his loved ones and shopping on Bryan's behalf incase he was too intoxicated to remember to do so himself.

Despite a shady origin and troubled personal life, Bryan is a hardworking member of XCOM and is always ready to take on new challenges on the battlefield. He has distinguished himself amoung his peers as a good guy to watch your back. Whenever I want to test experimental weapons, armour or genetic alterations, Bryan is first in line to get to grips with the new equipment. Should the day come where Bryan wishes to leave the military and seek purpose elsewhere I give my absolute recommendation and can asure potential employers that he will receive flawless references from the XCOM project.

TL;DR XCOM: Enemy Unknown makes you care for your soldiers

10/10

reviewText:
First off I'm not a fan of turn-based games but XCOM really blew my mind.
The gameplay is just so well made with it's cover system, the weapons and what damage they do to the environment and how you feel connected to your soldiers.
As each soldier has their own nationality, facial features and names (facial features and names can be changed) it makes every single one stand out and sometimes you'll do anything to keep them alive. There's also an option that prevents you to save during missions which will make you think twice about what move you're going to make as every single mistake can change everything during a mission.
There's 5 classes (6 in enemy within) all with their own very important roles. Each time they level you get to choose a perk in their skill tree, normally each class has their set perks to choose from but there's an option that makes the perks random so you could end up with a soldier that has a perfect set of perks from different classes.
XCOM also offers the ability to build up your own base, do research and create items and weapons and it's more or less up to you in what order you want to do things.

The Enemy Within expansion gives you a new class, a heavy cyborg/mech kind of class aswell as implants for regular soldiers that will boost them quite alot.

The missions in The Enemy Within are the same as in Enemy Unknown so if you think you'll only be playing the game once I would really recommend getting the expansion right away as it offers alot more options to your playthrough.

Even if you're normally not a turn-based gamer I would recommend trying this game, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
It's casual and hardcore at the same time due to its simple but working battle mechanics and permadeaths.

There're few things I really wished from this game:
1) Ability to scout the terrain before deploying troops. I'm confident that it's currently impossible to do, therefore most of the time you have to send an overall solid team on each mission, instead of adjusting it according to the battlefield.
2) Making the base development at least feel faster. It's terribly slow to do, although you're supposed to be the top organization on Earth fighting against the biggest threat in human history. It's just a game, but cmon, the support you're getting from other countries is pitiful.
3) Random damage spread is very unforgiving. It forces you to rely more on gadgets and abilities, which is good, but especially Overwatching is often worthless due to the pure hit chance. I'd prefer if it affected the amount of dealt damage rather than only deciding between hit and miss. So if the hit chance was 60% for 10 damage, it would still most likely do that 8-10 damage, a worse dice roll would result somehing between 0-4, but not always only 0.

If these points were fixed, it would be a nearly perfect game. Now it's occasionally quite frustrating, most of the time very nice and enjoyable, but just sometimes frustrating.

reviewText:
XCOM is a grid-based tactical game with some fun unit management.  A grid is a two dimensional field in which everything is partitioned off into tiles which all take up the exact same amount of space and have the same shape.  Each tile is arranged on the grid such that it's position in relation to all other tiles is exactly the same as any other tile's position in relation to the tiles that surround it.  Grids can continue on in any direction for as long as they need to.  You can think of grids as a sort of pattern that can be extended or cut short (made shorter or longer), but the pattern will stay the same.  Grids do not need to have a consistent shape, but the patterning of the tiles does need to remain consistent.  If you are still having trouble grasping the idea of grid I can suggest some additional reading:

Metric Spaces by Thomas Wieting (2013) [people.reed.edu/~wieting/essays/MetricSpaces.pdf]
The Amazing World of Grids by Harold Svenberg (1957)
Grids and Lowest Level Computational Methods by Paul Moore (1989)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Grid
http://etc.usf.edu/clipart/42600/42677/grid_42677_lg.gif

If you are still having trouble grasping the concept of grids I suggest you go back and re-read my introductory paragraph with the knowledge that you now have from your additional readings.  Yeah, I realize that that's a bit of a cop-out but I'm kind of at a loss for how to explain this any more clearly to you.  I really thing that you must be overthinking this, a grid is not something that you normally have to explain to people at all.  Even with children who do not know what a grid is you can show them some examples and they'll get the basic idea.  I mean you certainly don't need to be some sort of grid guru just to understand what I'm going to be saying in this review.  You really just need a basic understanding and some common knowledge.

Sorry, I think I came off a bit condescending there.  Let's try this again.  I know you can get this if you just take it slow and try to think critically.  Grids are made up of tiles, tiles are arranged inside of the grid in a constant pattern.  Really the tiles are just subdivisions of the area that the grid covers, a way of splitting up the space into many different parts that all have the same size and shape.

Now come on, don't be so hard on yourself, I KNOW you can do this!  You've come this far and I can't let you give up.  I want you to think about grids for an hour each day until you finally have a firm grasp on the matter.  All I ask is one hour.  Return once you've completed that for me, and good luck!

Well congratulations, you did it!  I know this road must have been long and hard for you but I think that you've achieved something truly remarkable.  I'm proud of you and I encourage you to be proud of yourself.  You've worked hard enough, go ahead and take the rest of the day off, as a present to yourself.  You've earned it!  Then once you've rested up get out there and seize the day with your newfound familiarity with grids!

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn-Based Strategy game centering on squad-level tactics. You are in command of XCOM, an organization devoted to fighting off the threat of alien invaders. Your mission is to protect the Earth from this invasion, stopping alien abductions, terror attacks on population centers, and otherwise keeping everyone from panicking and defunding your project, gradually accumulating superior weapons and technology from the aliens so that you have a fighting chance.


Overall, the game is quite strong; the macro-level stuff is fairly addictive in its skinner-box techniques as there is always something new which is going to come just around the corner, and the combat-level stuff works well enough, though it is not perfect either. On the whole, it really makes you want to play through the whole game, though at the very end of the game it may end up feeling a bit strange; there comes a point at which you are really in control of the situation and the earlier desperation goes away, and about that same point the research starts really drying up, meaning that if you take too long to finish the game, it could potentially get a bit dry; the last couple missions before I beat the game were the weakest in the game simply because I had figured it out and there was little threat from the game at that point.

Still, I played through and beat the game in three or four sittings, which is always a sign that a game has you hooked.

reviewText: A brilliant re-boot of a classic franchise, XCOM: Enemy Unknown puts players in charge of a shadowy mulit-national task force charged with defending Earth from alien invasion. There are essentially two games here; the first layer tasks players with strategic base management. From here, they will research technology, diplomacy, base and equipment construction, and personnel. The second layer of the game is the tactical turn-based squad battles. Some battles give the player certain assignments, such as escorting a VIP or capturing rather than killiing a hostile. Each shot counts, and failure could mean the permanent loss of agents. Each decision made, whether in the strategic map or the tactical battle map feels genuinely compelling. If you are a strategy fan, you don't want to miss out on XCOM.:EU!

reviewText:
First off I'm not a fan of turn-based games but XCOM really blew my mind.
The gameplay is just so well made with it's cover system, the weapons and what damage they do to the environment and how you feel connected to your soldiers.
As each soldier has their own nationality, facial features and names (facial features and names can be changed) it makes every single one stand out and sometimes you'll do anything to keep them alive. There's also an option that prevents you to save during missions which will make you think twice about what move you're going to make as every single mistake can change everything during a mission.
There's 5 classes (6 in enemy within) all with their own very important roles. Each time they level you get to choose a perk in their skill tree, normally each class has their set perks to choose from but there's an option that makes the perks random so you could end up with a soldier that has a perfect set of perks from different classes.
XCOM also offers the ability to build up your own base, do research and create items and weapons and it's more or less up to you in what order you want to do things.

The Enemy Within expansion gives you a new class, a heavy cyborg/mech kind of class aswell as implants for regular soldiers that will boost them quite alot.

The missions in The Enemy Within are the same as in Enemy Unknown so if you think you'll only be playing the game once I would really recommend getting the expansion right away as it offers alot more options to your playthrough.

Even if you're normally not a turn-based gamer I would recommend trying this game, you won't be disappointed.
