reviewText: A brilliant re-boot of a classic franchise, XCOM: Enemy Unknown puts players in charge of a shadowy mulit-national task force charged with defending Earth from alien invasion. There are essentially two games here; the first layer tasks players with strategic base management. From here, they will research technology, diplomacy, base and equipment construction, and personnel. The second layer of the game is the tactical turn-based squad battles. Some battles give the player certain assignments, such as escorting a VIP or capturing rather than killiing a hostile. Each shot counts, and failure could mean the permanent loss of agents. Each decision made, whether in the strategic map or the tactical battle map feels genuinely compelling. If you are a strategy fan, you don't want to miss out on XCOM.:EU!

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the original XCOM and I consider it to be possibly the best game of all time. The mix of tactics and strategy, the ability to scare the daylights out of you, with tough missions and excellent rewards meant it still has a place on my hard drive ven today.

So when they decided to change up the formula for the new XCOM, I was apprehensive. When I first played it, I thought it was good but not great. It just felt like it was missing too many tactical options. So while the game was certainly well done and a fresh new take on the series - while still remaining true to the turn based roots and source material - I felt it was missing something. I simply felt constrained by the tactical combat options. But it still is a solid game on its own. Just not a great one.

But with the expansion, this game feels complete. It's still not as good as the original, but it stands on its own two feet and is a great gaming experience. The combat is the central part of the game and it's generally well done. There are irritants of course, but it's good - and once you get deeper into the game with the meld options it becomes fantastic. You can build your squad of soldiers and really shape your approach to combat.

Plus, the production values in research, manufacturing and the overall story are pretty darn good too. These add on" components aren't very deep
date:
but you are forced to make difficult choices. Do you use that meld to boost your sniper or create a walking tank? Which nation do you sacrifice and who gets coverage from the alien invasion? Which mission do you go on? Do you try to save that soldier in a bad position or do you let him die? Meaningful choices are in every part of the game.

Now you might ask what's the expansion versus the base game and why did it make it so much better? I'll leave it to you to get the feature list from the store page. But in my opinion it wasn't so much the quantity of what they added but what was added gives players enough options to really approach the tactical battles the way they'd like. Do you want super-soldiers? Or do you prefer tough guys enhanced by Aliens-style exoskelletons that can punch an alien through a wall?

There are two big flaws in this game to me:

1. The missions aren't always interesting enough. There's an early one involving a ship (that floats
recommended: not flies) that's incredibly well done. It's tight
hoursPlayed:
tough and gripping. But that's the only real memorable mission in the game which is too bad. They could have done so much more with crafting some more interesting missions.

2. I hate that when you find a group of enemies they call get to run for cover before the fighting starts. It's a "gamey" decision that detracts from proper planning by the player.

Still
voteText: these are fairly minor warts given the fun I had with it. In my book the base game is solid and good. The expansion takes it to another level. It's still not as good as the original
helpfulPercent: but it's worthy of the name of the title and the best game of this style since the original.  This title - with the expansion - belongs in any gamer's library. Highly recommened."

reviewText:
Cons:
- Some 'random number generator' frustrations because of the way 'chance to hit' plays a big role in the game.  At 75% chance to hit, you can count on missing multiple times every couple of battles, which usually results in a teammate dying.  (And even though the game is kind of designed to let characters die now and again, it's actually such a big penalty that you do NOT want it to happen).  Even at max, 95% chance to hit, you'll get the occasional 2 or 3 in-a-row miss that drives you crazy.  Save often so you can quit and reload when someone dies.
- It's possible to ruin the game for yourself early on through the base management (the Sim City-ish bit).  I can't remember what it was, exactly, but one thing you can invest in results in the aliens levelling up.  Invest too much too early, and you'll be facing deadly aliens while you're still at low levels with no cash.  At that point it is literally impossible to win.  Definitely look up a couple of FAQs before you start, so you can avoid this.

Pros:
- Absolutely, utterly, everything else.
- The storyline is brilliant.  Intrigue, conspiracy, side-stories that tie in well with the main story, and gameplay and character and facility development that is heavily tied into the storyline.
- I was really surprised that the sci-fi alien attack setting was really well done.  Enough human development and intrigue focus that it didn't feel overly 'Star Trek-ky' or anything.
- Base and facility development isn't my kind of thing, but it was actually quite enjoyable in this case - more about levelling up aspects of your team than really micro managing everything Sim City style.  There was one thing related to how you level things up to avoid (see above), but otherwise it seemed secondary to the actual missions and battles.
- A good amount of variety amongst the types of soldiers you can get, with such different abilities that you really utilise them in different ways.  This really plays up the strategy aspect, as you decide which combinations of soldier types to use each battle.
- Having soldiers get injured, so they can't join missions for a while, is a great idea.  It forces you to play with combinations you might avoid otherwise, which adds extra variety and depth to the game.
- The abilities... and then the super duper awesome abilities that you won't believe you get later!  (Hint: If you read any FAQs, don't trust them when they say you need to focus on one set of the two super sets of options that come available.  You can afford to invest in both, and it's MUCH more fun to have both).
- Quite a good range of mission types and alien types keep the variety going.
- Other stuff that I can't remember or can't tell you for spoiler reasons.

The cons are pretty big, but you can avoid one if you read up on it a little and reduce the other by getting into regular saving habits.  I did both, and I honestly think XCOM is the best game I've played in years and years.  There are some other great games (like Divinity: Original Sin) that come close, but this edged them out because... it is simply THAT cool.

The countries that fund Xcom each desire youâ€™re services and as they get attacked it falls on you to resolve whatever situations arise. The aliens will attack three countries simultaneously and since you only own one transport ship (no matter what) you may only respond to one in every three attacks. When this occurs you will weigh the rewards and aid the wealthiest or most convenient countryâ€¦ the other two countries will â€œpanicâ€ and if neglected for long enough they will quit Xcom and withdraw a portion of your monthly fundingâ€¦ Heres the kickerâ€¦ every time a country is left unaddressed in a crisis their panic level will rise by 2â€¦. However every other country on the same continent will rise by one!  There are a few game mechanics that allow you to delay youâ€™re inevitable defeat but nothing to out rightly stop it. You must beat the game before you lose eight nations.

So to recap
1. You will buy aircraft in sets of four at a time and you can have a hundred soldiers on standby but you can only own one transport ship and therefore can only respond to one third of all alien related crisisâ€¦ Also the transport ship only seats six at a timeâ€¦ when upgradedâ€¦.
2. Countries will inevitably quit, when they quit you cannot provide any incentive to bring them back into the fold. You will lose when eight countries quit because no paramilitary group can perform efficiently without the support of Argintina, Nigeria, Cairo, South Africa, Brazil and three other second world (Iâ€™m feeling generous) nations.

Thatâ€™s the premise. What about the game play?

When the aliens â€œattackâ€ a city you usually get there after they have inflicted the maximum amount of damage they can given the ordinance at their disposal. Youâ€™ll walk through urban areas and note that despite a few corpses they are completely depopulated. The only sounds emanating from the city are non specific alien growling, I found it strongly nostalgic and reminiscent of Doom. Now the kicker is that the aliens arenâ€™t engaged in any particular activity when you discover them, in fact they donâ€™t actually exist on the level at all until a member of your squad reaches a predetermined point. Once you step on the games invisible red wire poof! a plethora of alien life appears. They promptly interrupt youâ€™re turn and fan out and occupy the best defensive or offensive positions. Since the game is ostensibly a strategy game you will scramble for better cover or attempt to flank themâ€¦ only to get counter flanked by a second or even third group of spawning aliens.

Hereâ€™s the fun part. The aliens cover more ground then you, they have more support skills and offensive abilities then you, they have significantly better aim then you, Before long they get guys that are tougher than yours. They even â€œwallhackâ€ and will target members of your squad that they havenâ€™t rightfully seen. The first rule of Xcom is that the aliens outnumber youâ€¦ on earth.

The core gameplay of any turn based squad strategy game is ultimately going to be about cover and how well cover is integrated into the actual game play. Well heres the word. Most enemies are able to traverse great distances on ground. Some of them also have abilities that directly negate or ignore cover. â€œThin menâ€ can spit venom over obstacles to hit soldiers they havenâ€™t seen. Floaters can fly off the map and reappear at its opposite end ext. In this game cover is over rated. Youâ€™re guys are going to be shot through walls, cars and hills. In turn Youâ€™re guysâ€¦ earthâ€™s last hope and the super elite of every nations military will consistently miss shots on enemies  in plain sight on level terrain with no hint of obstacles or cover in the way.

Recap
1. Youâ€™re soldiers are all near sighted. They can see for maybe thirty yards on a clear day, not counting obstacles. This game mechanic is done to hide the fact that the aliens will spawn at designated locations just outside youâ€™re field of vision.
2. The Alien AI is rudimentary at best. They will occupy defensive featuresâ€¦ If they spawn right next to them
3.. The strategic nature of the game is purely aesthetic. If you attempt to fan out and flank them you will only spawn more aliens and get caught in a cross fire.

In conclusion. Turn based strategy games are a niche genre and companies that cater to a niche get catered to by the niche. There is no logical need for improvement and their first priority is rightfully to keep their fans happy. An outsider will play this game and realize very quickly that while they thought they were taking home a strategy game they were actually getting a glorified version of Russian roulette, a random number generator. While it has great aesthetic value, strong writing and passable voice acting it brings very little to the table that wasnâ€™t present in the 90s and relies very heavily on mechanics that have been defunct since the days of John Romeroâ€¦ There are a number of mods that seek to improve Xcom and fix many of the aforementioned quirks but itâ€™ll be many years before I give Xcom a third chance. Until then if I get a strong urge to play a turn based strategy game Iâ€™ll return to 1997â€™s Final Fantasy Tactics which still stands at the top of the genre.

PS: *SPOILERS* The enemy is the aliens.

reviewText:
They told me it was good. Reviews, the zeitgeist, friends and relatives. XCOM is good they told me. I was disinterested. I was wrong.

A tactical tour-de-force not without its limitations and frustrations, and lacking in real artistic punch, XCOM is well worth a purchase.

You're handed command of a force tasked with stopping the alien invasion of earth. You have an underground base, which is essentially your menu screen giving you access to your soldiers and the customisation options available (both practical, such as gear they take into battle, and superficial options such as name or appearance can be altered here) and you choose your research projects, buy gear and generally make the big decisions about how you want to save the world.
Once you launch a mission, various different types of which exist, you're given an isometric viewpoint and turn based control of your squad and told to, in most cases eliminate all trace of the alien menace.
You will carefully position your squad in cover, your sniper on overwatch, your assault on the frontlines, edging your way through the fog of war until aliens are spotted and it will be going well. You'll remove the first batch and feel smug, clear the map, return to base and congratulate yourself on a job well done. You conduct missions in each of the 18 countries signed up to the XCOM project, and keep the panic from spreading with your successes.
Soon however when the stronger, move maneuverable, harder to kill aliens show up in missions and start ruining your plans by spitting poisonous clouds just where you wanted to be, or flanking your oh so carefully positioned sniper who has been with you since Mission #1 and sending her to her perma-death covered on plasma burns, you will be livid that you've been out gunned and out thought. After liming through the mission your battered squad return to base where your decision to build a research lab instead of a workshop isn't looking so great, Germany is on the verge of leaving the alliance and taking funding with them, because you chose to respond to a threat in Japan last mission as the reward was more use to you at the time, but the earth needs saving, and with a little luck you still think you can manage it. Compelling and wonderful.

reviewText:
There's a stereotype that games make you turn OFF your brain, and are a mindless slug through mundane, disengaging setpieces, This game is a living, breathing, tangible contradiction to that claim. In this part turn-based startegy part base management game, you protect Earth from an invading alien force. Sound familiar? Just another alien game? Rest assured, this game is much more than it appears to be, and is a rare treat for tose looking for a game that pushes you cognitive abilities.

I have never felt my brain go into strategic-overdrive as it did when I played this game. Fair-warning, this game does NOT hold your hand, and to avoid losing (that's right, you can LOSE a 20 hour game) you'll have to be both quick-witted and an effective  base manager. Only those who conduct the proper research, manage resources and money efficiently, smartly equip their soldiers, and maintain their relationships with the countries in the XCOM council will succeed in their turn-based skirmishes, where players control up to six marines to eliminate the alien threat.

The duality of this game is one of its strengths, as the ground battles and the base management go hand-in-hand. Didn't invest in the titan armor research? Well I guess your soldiers are going to perish an unnatural death down on the ground. Failed to protect a member of the council on an important mission? Well I guess Nigeria is pulling out of the XCOM project and thus cutting its funding.

Speaking of failure, that is also another one of the game's strengths, and something you'll be deeply terrified of. You can name and customize your soldiers, and eventually you become attached to them (think pokemon), arming your favorite guy to the teeth and giving him a badass nickname. And these soldiers will go through Hell, facing a mulitude of different alien classes, each with completely distinct looks and effective strategies to use againts. However, your precious characters can die permenantly in these missions if you don't do everything with clockwork effiency. That same urgency extends to the diplomatic side of the game. If you screw up to many times, enough nations will leave the council and you LOSE. This sort of challenge is rare in modern games and is a welcome revival.

All in all, if you're looking for a exhilerating game that engages your brain, tis one's for you.

reviewText:
This is a review for the XCOM along with all the dlc's, so that means XCOM: Enemy Within.

So far, this game is fantastic, very unique gameplay compare to basic turn based strategy games. Variety of options included for those who wants a challenge or simply prefer the game easier. This game does have a multiplayer as well, but I have not yet tested that out, the singleplayer however, is simply amazing.

The game involves you controlling a squad of members, taking cover and strategic positions on the battlefield while attempting to make tactical decisions focusing on objective as well as keeping your squad alive. There are several classes as well, base classes are Assault, Support, Heavy, and Sniper. You can genetically modify those classes or even machin-nize your soldiers to make them exceed farther. As game progresses, the game also requires you to research and construct facilities in order to advance in both tech and more of overall diplomatic control. One of the game's biggest element are countries under the council, as aliens attack, you would be force to make decisions that pro's one of the countries but con's the other countries, ultimately influencing the panic level. When a panic level hits 5 bars, a country would likely to leave the XCOM project, making it so they no longer can fund you. When a certain number of countries leave XCOM, the game is over.

Graphic: 8/10
Explanation: The performance is very well done, and I do enjoy the action-figure type of graphic, the FPS caps at 62 for smooth, that isn't a problem for me. However, I believe there's space for graphic improvement, overall a 8 which is pretty godo.

Plot: 7/10
Explanation: The game does have pretty good plot overall, however, XCOM in my opinion is one of those games where you play for the gameplay and the research, spending time trying to find out why aliens are attacking. So plot is less reliant when it comes to overall feel.

Gameplay: 10/10
Explanation: The gameplay is absolutely amazing, first of all it's pretty unique compare to modern day's games, it combines RTS aspects with turn based TRPG. Really polished, always neat stuff to look forward to, and overall if you enjoy strategy games, I would say you would like this as well. The sci-fi theme is a plus for me.

Replayability: 8/10
Explanation: This is more sort of my current feel with the game, with Second Wave (Additional Game Options) I would certainly not mind replaying a game maybe twice for a different route and a different result, as for others I can certainly see less replay value for them. I would not rely however, on multiplayer for replayability over singleplayer.

Overall: 9/10
Conclusion: Great game, if you are considering or wondering rather or not to get this game, don't think about it, add it to your cart right now. I got it during the steam sale from around $25 along with all the dlc's, which was a steal, at full price it is very well worth every penny. One thing I would say is, don't get too attach to your squad, they will most likely die hehe.

reviewText:
If you came here looking for a classic x-com game, you came to the wrong place. The aliens may be the same, and in fact I'd say they did a good job of updating all the aliens to be something new and unique, but this has almost none of the traditional x-com charm and difficulty. Everything is based on a very simple cover system... either you're in cover, or you're not. You don't shoot in the direction of enemies, like you do in the original games, but rather you shoot at a single enemy, and either you hit, or you miss. If you miss, you might get lucky and blow up their cover.

The game operates on a mob group system. Aliens are in groups, and if they spot you, they get a cinematic in which they run in to cover. This means that if a group of aliens has not seen you this turn, they will not shoot you during their turn, so the threat is minimal. Even at the start of the game, you're fielding a squad of 4 guys vs. many aliens. Later on you go up to a whopping 6, making the aliens feel very weak... how are we even losing this war?

All that said, if you take away the xcom, the game is a functional TBT. It's fairly decent, and can be quite enjoyable. If you're looking for x-com, skip it and go buy xenonauts, or go help out with any of the open source fan projects out there.

Sadly, the game is also riddled with bugs. Sometimes you will be unable to shoot an enemy, even though they can shoot you. Sometimes your troops will end up walking somewhere they can't go, resulting in them being stuck for the mission if they can't fly. There's many others, especially in multiplayer, so only get it if you're interested in TBT. It's a good introduction of the genre to those who wouldn't normally play such.

reviewText:
If you came here looking for a classic x-com game, you came to the wrong place. The aliens may be the same, and in fact I'd say they did a good job of updating all the aliens to be something new and unique, but this has almost none of the traditional x-com charm and difficulty. Everything is based on a very simple cover system... either you're in cover, or you're not. You don't shoot in the direction of enemies, like you do in the original games, but rather you shoot at a single enemy, and either you hit, or you miss. If you miss, you might get lucky and blow up their cover.

The game operates on a mob group system. Aliens are in groups, and if they spot you, they get a cinematic in which they run in to cover. This means that if a group of aliens has not seen you this turn, they will not shoot you during their turn, so the threat is minimal. Even at the start of the game, you're fielding a squad of 4 guys vs. many aliens. Later on you go up to a whopping 6, making the aliens feel very weak... how are we even losing this war?

All that said, if you take away the xcom, the game is a functional TBT. It's fairly decent, and can be quite enjoyable. If you're looking for x-com, skip it and go buy xenonauts, or go help out with any of the open source fan projects out there.

Sadly, the game is also riddled with bugs. Sometimes you will be unable to shoot an enemy, even though they can shoot you. Sometimes your troops will end up walking somewhere they can't go, resulting in them being stuck for the mission if they can't fly. There's many others, especially in multiplayer, so only get it if you're interested in TBT. It's a good introduction of the genre to those who wouldn't normally play such.

-Quick Review-
XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn based strategy game, which prioritizes on micromanagement skills, coupled with sound field decisions and employ's many rogue type elements. In short: it's a Sci-fi strategy game.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You're the worlds primary defense against Alien Invasion, you are the leader of the XCOM Project. Your job is simple: beat the aliens. But accomplishing that task isn't so simple, you need t keep the world nations calm, research technology, and then have your engineers create whatever the scientists have cooked up.

Game Play: Game play is where this game really shines, the graphics are fun to see, it's easy to implement many unorthodox strategies, you get to customize your base, but the most important investment of your resources will be in weapons and armor.

It is very important to emphases the difficulty of this game; unless you happen to be some military genius or a natural at this game (either could be true, and you still need to save before and after each battle) you will need to save your progress and reload from that save state. On the easiest difficulty the aliens will have no problem blowing up the poor S.O.B. you left out of cover because you misclicked... Trust me, he/she will be dead or in uselessly low health.

By the end of this game I had recovered a terrible habit/condition... called Save before you do anything". I developed this habit while playing Pokemon and Knights of the Old Republic. Upon playing this game I was saving before and after every battle.

reviewText: XCOM's focus is on single-player and in this day and age is a good thing! The long campaign is challenging enough on Normal, with a big leap in enemy threat and movement on Classic - both of which are enhanced immeasurably by Ironman mode, which removes the temptation to save-cheat. The last difficulty level, Impossible, rightly so, your soldiers will die, a lot! This game is a winner. So much craft has gone into its atmosphere, into small details that together add enormous depth and flavour to the world: the occasional conversations overheard while fiddling around in the base; the mission loading screen, which gives you a view of the troops inside the carrier, fidgeting and tapping their feet in transit; soldiers acquiring nicknames after a few missions; the memorial room for fallen warriors, with a cork board of photos on the wall, which records their names. Near the campaign's end, there's a direct tribute to the original game's designers, the Gollop brothers, accompanied by an achievement called 'On the Shoulders of Giants'. It's a beautiful touch, a nod from one development team to another across the generations. They have something in common now. In their own time and place, each made a fantastic game called XCOM.

reviewText:
XCOM integrates a lot of interesting features and systems into its gameplay. I was looking forward to playing it for its tactical turn-based combat system, but found myself having more fun with the base management, research and engineering system. However, it does not come without any faults, I encountered numerous bugs, ranging from the non-saving options menu (that I have to re-configure each time I play) to buggy in-game user interface.

The meat of the game, tactical turn-based combat, was an OK experience (Line of sight system isn't perfect, sometimes an alien is right in front of you and your soldier can't see them, I didn't enjoy the Overwatch mechanic, and randomly activating 3 alien camps with one movement is not fun). The best part of this game is the squad system, you get to customize and outfit all your soldiers;  there being different classes, abilities trees, weapons and equipment.

Sidenote: I do criticize Firaxis for releasing XCOM: Enemy Within as a standalone game on consoles, but on PC you have to buy the $32 base game XCOM: Enemy Unknown before you can play the $32 Enemy Within, which is just the same campaign as XCOM:EU with some extra missions and updates. I would recommend XCOM: EU, but buy Enemy Within only if you like the base game and if it goes on sale.

reviewText: X-Com: Enemy Unknown is not quite the easiest game to get into and not as self-explanatory as it could be, but the four things it is should be more than enough to warrant a recommendation. It's unique, it's intuitive, it's absorbing and it's a hell of a lot of fun. The game is essentially a strategy RPG where you have to plan every move you make meticulously and with attention to military squad and cover tactics, but you have to manage the back end as well. Engaging in a bit of building and management simulation akin to a 4x game to make sure that your troops are able to keep up with the enemy's technology levels. It's incredibly engaging to pull off a perfect mission, or have to make difficult decisions where one side of the game has to make sacrifices for the other. The game can be very unfair or even luck-based at times, but it's easy to get back into and it can make hopeless battles if not fun then still engaging and rewarding on a more personal level (in an emergent storytelling sort of way). Consider this one a strong general recommendation, walking a perfect line between accessibility and compexity.

reviewText: Possibly the most organic dual-mode game that has come out in the past few years.  The strategic mode leaves you researching and contructing a bunch of toys to use and looking forward to the missions where you'll get new resources and things to research, and the tactical missions leave you with new enemy after new enemy and all sorts of items to bring back.  It evokes the feel of the original very well.  I'm not the biggest fan of the change to a much more colourful and Fisher-Price type look of the tech and in particular the weapons, which all look like childrens toys, but otherwise the visual look and feel is implemented very well and perhaps just as importantly consistently.  The game just gels very well together in terms of gameplay, visual design, and sound design.  The production values are high and so is the fun.  The only real thing I felt was a misstep other than some elements of the visual design is the difficulty.  While the original could be tortuous sometimes and some scaling back was probably neccesary in today's gaming market, the game is actually pretty easy on all but the highest difficulty, as long as you stick with troops with good stats and stay on top of research and production of new weapons.  One of the disappointing things for me in that regards was the chrysallids.  In the original they were Aliens-inspired creatures that would zombify your men or civillians, and when you killed the zombie a new chrysallid would emerge.  It made things very frantic when you saw one.  Comparatively, the new chrysallids look and feel very different.  While they do have an instant-kill melee attack (the originals actually didnt, except insofar as they hit like a brick s**thouse), the zombies are mostly unthreatening enemies and there's no extra chrysallid when you kill them.  It effective neuters what was one of the original games greatest threats, because of how quickly a chrysallid could ambush and spawn more chrysallids.\n\nThose gripes aside, its an engaging and well-done game which remains a time sink for me to this day.  The only turn-based strategy game in the last decade which has had me going just one more turn""

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown

Or

How to survive an alien invasion 101

Good morning class! Welcome to your new â€œoptionalâ€ class of this semester. In light of the recent alien threat we will be going over how You can contribute in defending this muddy patch of dirt called Earth!

Step 1 â€“ People will die

Since you will be commanding the elite unit that is supposed to be the first and last line of defense, it is a good idea to complete the tutorial. Regardless what kind of veteran you consider yourself, getting used to the new control of your units is always useful, especially during a mission with no real stakes. Even if you think thatâ€™s below you, the tutorial will remind you of a small fact: soldiers die. As a general advice donâ€™t get used to your buddies too much, unless you are playing on the lowest difficulty â€“ in which case you can leave your man card on my desk on your way out. Oh and one more thing; people who fail my class get promoted to rookie status, get awarded with granddadâ€™s old rifle and army jacket, and can go prove themselves on the front lines.

Step 2 â€“ Dig a hole

While your less intelligent classmates are fighting on the frontlines, you will be sitting in the comfort of the anthill you call your base. Using all the technology available to man, the faceless representatives of Earthâ€™s nations have decided to dig you a hole on a continent of your choosing, with different advantages. Europe for example will allow you to maintain your research facilities at lowered costs, while Africa will make sure that any unfortunate extraterrestrial you manage to bring home will spill their secrets much quicker. Later on you will have to dig deeper to expand your new bachelor pad. In order to give you a chance in your ongoing fight with the seemingly endless alien armada, you will have to build additional manufacturing, research and training facilities, all the while making sure you have enough energy to run the whole thing.

Step 3 â€“ Sun Tzu saysâ€¦

Knowing your enemy is half the battle. When fighting aliens with vastly superior numbers and technology that makes the Silicon Valley look like the arts and crafts class from fourth graders, it is pretty much the entire battle. The way ahead lies in collecting as many alien artifacts as possible, bringing back their corpses and even live specimens as time goes on. The German ex-mistress turned scientist Dr. Vahleen will â€œprobeâ€ these poor animals and provide you with new technologies, while the obligatory generic Japanese Dr. Shen will manufacture whatever comes out of her twisted mind. As you fight the new specimens of the alien invaders, their remains will let you upgrade your weapons and armor, produce better aircrafts, or even unlock special abilities for some of your soldiers. Falling behind on these will decrease the already small chance of survival of your faithful bullet sponges, causing you to fail essential missions.

Step 4 â€“ The coin is mightier than the sword

Even though the world is about to end, nothing is free. While the visitors from outer space managed to turn back inflation by about 70 years, everything you build or develop will cost you money. Your afternoon world saving club is financed by 16 countries who are willing to pay and provide you manpower if you provide them protection. This extortion racket works as long they are actively protected. To translate, you will get payment from countries you watch over with satellites. If they get too many unregistered visitors they will â€œpanicâ€. Every month the council will evaluate your performance. If the panic meter is full at the end of the month, the country will leave the project, and fend for itself. This is something you should try to avoid at all costs, because you will lose potential income and the bonus provided by protecting an entire continent. Should you get low on the almighty mulah, you have multiple options; you can sell alien parts or some of your weapons to other countries, or if they give you one, complete council missions. Managing your finances is very important even in the face of total annihilation. Running out of money while not the end of the world, makes the game a lot harder.

Step 5 - Time to get technical

Defending Earth in XCOM is a tough but fair experience. While the game will give you equal opportunities to smash your mouse against the wall, or shout victoriously as that damn alienâ€™s head blows up, it is not without its flaws. Shooting through walls is common. While this is understandable with some of the later weapons, it is painful to watch as your soldier executes a fatal shot through walls they canâ€™t even see through. The camera sometimes takes angles where nothing is visible, and no amount of rotation or zooming can make it better. Aiming with rockets or grenades is a pain to say the least, often making you miss perfectly valid shots. Needless to say, these are almost always critical situations since using explosives means losing alien artifacts. The system otherwise is fairly easy to learn, and while certain useful tricks, such as the importance of constructing the same type of buildings next to each other are easy to miss, the game tries itâ€™s best to explain everything.

Three stage plan: 1.We engage the aliens. 3. We liberate Earth and celebrate. Easy right?

The road to victory will be long, and undoubtedly challenging. I canâ€™t promise anything but blood, toil, tears, and sweat.
The multiplayer option allows you and your friends to choose sides, and use those nasty alien powers on each other, while equipping everyone with that mega laser rifle you could never afford in-game. While sometimes laggy, the multiplayer works fine 90% of the time.

In conclusion, for anyone who likes turn-based tactical shooters, this alien shooting, Earth defending, base building 2K creation is a must. A true spiritual successor of the original, the game will satisfy the hardcore fans of the original, as well as newcomers to the franchise.

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown

Or

How to survive an alien invasion 101

Good morning class! Welcome to your new â€œoptionalâ€ class of this semester. In light of the recent alien threat we will be going over how You can contribute in defending this muddy patch of dirt called Earth!

Step 1 â€“ People will die

Since you will be commanding the elite unit that is supposed to be the first and last line of defense, it is a good idea to complete the tutorial. Regardless what kind of veteran you consider yourself, getting used to the new control of your units is always useful, especially during a mission with no real stakes. Even if you think thatâ€™s below you, the tutorial will remind you of a small fact: soldiers die. As a general advice donâ€™t get used to your buddies too much, unless you are playing on the lowest difficulty â€“ in which case you can leave your man card on my desk on your way out. Oh and one more thing; people who fail my class get promoted to rookie status, get awarded with granddadâ€™s old rifle and army jacket, and can go prove themselves on the front lines.

Step 2 â€“ Dig a hole

While your less intelligent classmates are fighting on the frontlines, you will be sitting in the comfort of the anthill you call your base. Using all the technology available to man, the faceless representatives of Earthâ€™s nations have decided to dig you a hole on a continent of your choosing, with different advantages. Europe for example will allow you to maintain your research facilities at lowered costs, while Africa will make sure that any unfortunate extraterrestrial you manage to bring home will spill their secrets much quicker. Later on you will have to dig deeper to expand your new bachelor pad. In order to give you a chance in your ongoing fight with the seemingly endless alien armada, you will have to build additional manufacturing, research and training facilities, all the while making sure you have enough energy to run the whole thing.

Step 3 â€“ Sun Tzu saysâ€¦

Knowing your enemy is half the battle. When fighting aliens with vastly superior numbers and technology that makes the Silicon Valley look like the arts and crafts class from fourth graders, it is pretty much the entire battle. The way ahead lies in collecting as many alien artifacts as possible, bringing back their corpses and even live specimens as time goes on. The German ex-mistress turned scientist Dr. Vahleen will â€œprobeâ€ these poor animals and provide you with new technologies, while the obligatory generic Japanese Dr. Shen will manufacture whatever comes out of her twisted mind. As you fight the new specimens of the alien invaders, their remains will let you upgrade your weapons and armor, produce better aircrafts, or even unlock special abilities for some of your soldiers. Falling behind on these will decrease the already small chance of survival of your faithful bullet sponges, causing you to fail essential missions.

Step 4 â€“ The coin is mightier than the sword

Even though the world is about to end, nothing is free. While the visitors from outer space managed to turn back inflation by about 70 years, everything you build or develop will cost you money. Your afternoon world saving club is financed by 16 countries who are willing to pay and provide you manpower if you provide them protection. This extortion racket works as long they are actively protected. To translate, you will get payment from countries you watch over with satellites. If they get too many unregistered visitors they will â€œpanicâ€. Every month the council will evaluate your performance. If the panic meter is full at the end of the month, the country will leave the project, and fend for itself. This is something you should try to avoid at all costs, because you will lose potential income and the bonus provided by protecting an entire continent. Should you get low on the almighty mulah, you have multiple options; you can sell alien parts or some of your weapons to other countries, or if they give you one, complete council missions. Managing your finances is very important even in the face of total annihilation. Running out of money while not the end of the world, makes the game a lot harder.

Step 5 - Time to get technical

Defending Earth in XCOM is a tough but fair experience. While the game will give you equal opportunities to smash your mouse against the wall, or shout victoriously as that damn alienâ€™s head blows up, it is not without its flaws. Shooting through walls is common. While this is understandable with some of the later weapons, it is painful to watch as your soldier executes a fatal shot through walls they canâ€™t even see through. The camera sometimes takes angles where nothing is visible, and no amount of rotation or zooming can make it better. Aiming with rockets or grenades is a pain to say the least, often making you miss perfectly valid shots. Needless to say, these are almost always critical situations since using explosives means losing alien artifacts. The system otherwise is fairly easy to learn, and while certain useful tricks, such as the importance of constructing the same type of buildings next to each other are easy to miss, the game tries itâ€™s best to explain everything.

Three stage plan: 1.We engage the aliens. 3. We liberate Earth and celebrate. Easy right?

The road to victory will be long, and undoubtedly challenging. I canâ€™t promise anything but blood, toil, tears, and sweat.
The multiplayer option allows you and your friends to choose sides, and use those nasty alien powers on each other, while equipping everyone with that mega laser rifle you could never afford in-game. While sometimes laggy, the multiplayer works fine 90% of the time.

In conclusion, for anyone who likes turn-based tactical shooters, this alien shooting, Earth defending, base building 2K creation is a must. A true spiritual successor of the original, the game will satisfy the hardcore fans of the original, as well as newcomers to the franchise.

reviewText:
Never touch ironman mode, always get engineers ASAP and spam satellites like you're giving them away at an Elvis concert,  and put your trust in grenades. Follow those rules, and you should soon find yourself having a good time.

More faithful spiritual successors to XCOM exist out there, but a big part of the fun behind XCOM: Enemy Unknown is that the process of tactical micromanagement is scaled back, and the progression towards researching fun gadgets and hardware is expedited.

The expansion pack, Enemy Within, might at first appear to lock all the goodies behind perilously tantalising resource nodes, but most players should be skilled enough to obtain a few meld canisters by the end of the first month, and the actual cost of the facilities and tech needed to convert the new currency to even bigger, shinier toys is cheaper than might be expected. Everybody can now have their very own Mecha Hitler for a low, low cost.

There isn't any point in questioning the logic of XCOM. Yes, the governments of the world are silly for expecting their ultra-elite special counter-invasion task force to fund their own operations through means tantamount to bribery, corruption and smuggling of unregulated organs and explosives to third world countries. It's also absurd that such an organisation as XCOM is only capable of recruiting raw cadets who've barely passed basic training, instead of opening up channels with the Navy SEALS, the SAS, the KGB or something. If it was up to me, then XCOM would only recruit from Nepal. Get some Gurkhas to wreck some grey meat. That said, come the end of the game, the XCOM project does appear to have an excellent knack for selecting psychics, so maybe the strategy of recruiting miopic idiot savants was smart after all.

Lastly, the controls can be very contrived. Sometimes you'll be fighting against the cursor to get onto the right square, as the screen keeps swapping between Z-levels. A control may work better for some people, because if your mouse button is sensitive and you sometimes misclick, then prepare to cry as your cyborg colonel sprints the full distance out into the open and spreads his cheeks for muton sausage.

This game will make you want to drop the dev team into a shark cage dangling above the eldritch shrieking of an ancient cosmic entity, but when RNGesus, or Nuffle, or whoever you pray to for high percentages is on your side, you'll feel such euphoria as your sniper gets an overwatch clutch crit on a stampeding chrysalid. Of course the damage counter will only register a 4 and the alien beast proceeds to go all Starship Troopers on your finest support medic, but hey, that's XCOM (I hate you Firaxis, xeno scum)

reviewText:
I was gifted this game and I guess I let it sit unplayed for too long! It's a fun strategy game that I found myself pretty invested in after only about an hour. While a lot of people knew what they were getting into because of the original game, I was unfamiliar with it.

The game is a fairly straightforward strategy game along with a base building element. You receive periodic funds and materials from missions to either upgrade gear for your soldiers, research technologies, and keep the world at peace with satellite coverage and UFO interception. The game does a pretty good job of making sure you aren't able (at least not easily) to do everything, so you have to somewhat plan out what you want to do in order to make sure things go smoothly.

The way the campaign progresses in pretty neat. At least, I hadn't seen it before. The game will tell you a specific thing to research, or item to build, or facility to construct, but the game doesn't seem to give you a deadline to do it. If you wanted, you could just kept the game going forever. But at the same time, going for too long without being able to protect the council/countries means that you have to keep progression in mind. It almost seems a little like Persona, of all things.

The core gameplay was pretty great, there is a ton on emphasis on positioning. Cover is basically the determinant of whether your unit will live or die. I lost 3 units pretty fast before I started being more careful. It's always really neat in these types of games to watch as units fall into roles and favorites become clear over the course the of the missions. I ended up with 2 snipers (which are fairly over powered, as everyone has probably heard) 2 supports, a heavy, and an assault. Each one ended up being used in a way that felt organic. I didn't need to meticulously plan, I just tried things to see what worked and what didn't and it all flowed so well.

I wished class changes could be decided. Unsure why it had to be random. I had other issues with manual saves and weird locks up that happened if a certain outcome was forced (say, attacking two of the elites with a grenade, they normally have a reaction cutscene but didn't work with 2 of them). I also wished there were a few more things fixed in place instead of just random missions on procudural maps. The few that were there were pretty nice. Some more enemy variety would have been good too, couple annoying recolors with are just boring.

On normal, the base game got a bit easy but the last mission certainly upped the difficulty. Once you know what works, you simply just repeat it every mission while spending your money at the base. For me that meant keeping snipers back, having a shotgun running around, and a tank absorbing blows while some medics pranced about. So the game loses a little magic at this point, but luckily this is right as the campaign was ending so it didn't overstay its welcome.  I am also hopeful that the expansion content will help some of these issues. I am certainly interested in trying it at some point down the road.

reviewText: Ever played Final Fantasy Tactics? This is waaay better! Manage your soldiers, assign new abilities as they increase in rank, build their weapons and shoot some aliens! No two matches feel the same, as the AI offers new challenges every time: as soon as you begin to feel comfortable there comes along a new species, forcing you to rethink your approach. What's better is that there is no single way to play the game, but you have to adapt to your base layout and to your soldiers' classes. Immersive game world, very detailed but not hard on your computer specs, so it's always very smooth. Beyond base management, research and engineering the battlefield is the game's strong point, and I guarantee you'll think the AI cheats when your colonel misses a 95% shot, and you'll swear and shout at the screen whenever your squad faces unforeseen annihilation; you will cry like a baby girl when you meet the Sectopod! Yeah, it's that immersive.\nAlso consider getting the Enemy Within DLC, it expands the game adding maps and features like genetic mods and freakin' MECHS! Worth having but pricey, maybe wait for a sale as the base game is fine as it is, and that's saying A LOT in these days.

reviewText:
First off, this is a good game, it has solid mechanics and it is fun to play but there are problems (Disclaimer: I am a complete fan of the original)

Having said that, it is a pale shadow of the mighty first game from which it takes its name (And even X-COM: Apocalypse) and it appears to be a syndrome that a lot of remakes suffer. The problem could be called Streamlining" (Total War Rome 2 has this problem as well).

1st is the research tree which is significantly smaller than the original. There is only one advanced Interceptor and very few weapons for it to research. The squad sizes are also very small (4-6) compared to the original so when you lose someone experienced it hurts a lot! (Losing 1 or 2 people in a mission early on can cripple your chances of completing it.) The maps are smaller and the mechanics of engaging enemies (Small groups that get their own "!" animation when you come across them) is disappointing.

Base building has been made much less interesting since in the original your base could be invaded (and you could have multiple bases). The X-COM: Enemy Within expansion does actually have a base defense mission but it is scripted
recommended: and how you built your base does not come into it.\n\nWhich brings me to my main problem with the new X-COM. I do not feel like the Commander of X-COM. In the original there were no scripted events

reviewText:
Pros: It has some great strategic depth to it with turn-based squad battles, and customization of your troops is more fun than it should be.  The game does a good job of putting a lot of weight into each choice you make, because you really feel it when you lose one of your soldiers, and it sucks.  Other than the occasional RNG bs crit damaging one of your guys, or causing a pointblank shot to miss, the difficulty is spot on.  You can't just rush your guys around the map and hope for the best, you actually have to think about your moves and how to win.

Cons: Story isn't much to tell, and is definitely not the center of the game.  There are a few minor bugs such as camera angles freaking out with the action cam, but nothing game breaking.  There is supposedly a bug in the last mission where the game will just hang up on the enemy turn (I haven't run into this myself, but I saw it happen on a livestream), but with the autosave happening every turn its more just a minor hassle to restart the game and reload the last save.

Overall:  Excellent game, if you like turn-based strategy this is a must have.  While I have not played the original I have heard that it is NOT the same game, but that being said its worth it to pick up, especially on sale.

8/10

reviewText:
XCOM:EU is what changed my opinion on turn-based strategy games. I usually hate those games and find them annoying/boring. This game completely made me change my mind. The Earth is under siege... not by one kind of E.T.'s.. but by several, so that is a new addition to most alien based games/movies. You don't forcefully start in the US, like most Alien Abductions happen. You control a party of 5(then more) soldiers and fight against the alien hordes in turn-based combat. Each soldier can then level up after each mission they finished and gain ranks and classes. Be careful, your soldiers WILL die sooner or later. Use your Saves/Loads.

>I'd give it a 10/10(pretty subjective but whatever)
>Pros: New approach to Alien Invasions, interesting RPG elements, fun combat, challenging but not impossible, ability to build and progress your base.
>Cons: Movement of some soldiers is visually tedious and ugly sometimes(cinematics as well), sometimes repetitive alien cinematics(always follow the same formula)

reviewText:
define: ambiguous

XCOM is a good game. And it could be soooo much better. Enter: a mod for the rescue.

The game offers a strategical management-layer with a time-compression feature and turn-based tactical missions in which you have to fight aliens with your squads. This combination works well and keeps you coming back. It starts great: there is a lot to do (research, building equipment, managing your soldiers...), the slick interface is doing its magic, you get your first valuable veterans, your abilities increase and everything is new and shiny. Nice pace and a good sense of progression.

And then you notice the first oddities: the line-of-sight system is a joke. This game creates its very own reality and logic, but it's easy enough to adapt to this. You will get a feeling for this weird reality. The cover system works despite being laughable at times and being far from realistic.

This game has countless little weaknesses. The strategic layer suffers a bit from being extremely streamlined. The game is keeping you busy with artificial difficulty and urgency. The panic system is erratic and a big clusterâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ of frustrating randomness. I did not feel threatened by aliens assaulting Earth but screwed by the developers. The late-game is lacking in content, as if they made the game and then cut away the Enemy Within" expansion. It's disappointing and left me behind unsatisfied.

Still I highly recommend the game despite all its weaknesses. It's a flawed gem and it can really suck you in. The tactical missions are exciting and reward bold moves just as much as they have a tendency to punish you for not being careful. Here eliminating the randomness becomes a satisfying challenge (destroy the cover first
date: finish off the enemy AFTER). It gives you perks and equipment to react to new threats and keeps things interesting. On the strategical layer the rigid schedule of scripted events makes for a more beginner-friendly experience. Many people will appreciate the ease that comes with a somewhat predictable course of events. Like it always is: the strengths of the game really highlight the weaknesses. And at the end of the day it is among the limited number of games i have finished more than once without ever being bored. Just don't expect a faithful recreation of the old XCOM games.\n\nThe expansion addresses the lack of content
recommended: but most problems persist. All that being said: I highly recommend the mod "Long War" (EW required!). It overhauls the game in many aspects. It will give you a much deeper experience. It turns XCOM from an "Invasion Simulator Light" into a well thought out strategy game with a great sense of consequence. It forces you to think and actually punishes you for messing up. But it also gives you the chance to undo your mistakes. And suddenly you really feel like you are defending Earth against terrifying aliens. It's what veterans crave!"

reviewText:
Just like with film industry, gaming industry seems to run out of new ideas, so now we have remakes of once popular games. Nothing wrong with that, except that many times movie/game suffers in process and its not as fun as it used to be. Good example of that seems to be Point Break (original was with Patrick Swayze, Keanu Reeves and Gary Busey) where new movie did not even come close to original.
I used to spend hours playing original UFO (on Amiga, PS and PC) and have it played even last year with help from OpenXcom (requires original DOS files to work, updates game and makes it Win7/Win10 compatible, don't need DOSBox) and I was very wary how this new game will play, but as soon as you do tutorial you can see that many of good things from original game are back.

On positive side, there is less base management (actually, you have only 1 base to worry about) and new use of laboratory and production seems to be more developed for consoles rather then for PC, but missions are still lots of fun and there are many nice touches, like rotating camera that can follow your troop, voice and comments from troop as well aliens sounds well made.

There are some glitches (firing trough the wall and random crashes), but nothing few saves can't fix. :)

If you like turn based game with management system and alien killing fun - this is game for you!

reviewText:
Most of the games I play, I'm more interested in the story, the world or the astmosphere than in the pure mechanics. With some games, for example the Hitman series, I'm almost exclusively interested in the systems behind the gameplay. XCOM resides in a weird spot in between. It immerses players in a tense atmosphere and at the same time presents a complex and multifaceted strategy game.

It feels nostalgic but plays modern. Some parts are generic and videogame-y, but it get's you completely immersed in the feeling of being a commander, fighting for the survival of human life on earth. It's complex, but accessible. It's a challanging game, but never unfair. It's imperssive how well every little part of this game, from the interplay of the two different strategic layers to the last piece of UI, is designed.

Everytime I talk about XCOM, I can't do anything else but praise it. It's one of those games I'd give a 10/10, if I believed such ratings were adequate. A truly great video game.

reviewText:
I'm normally not that into strategy games, especially when they're turn based. Somehow they feel slow, and I just want to unwind without thinking about things too much. But Xcom managed to pull me right in. It succesfully mixes turn based strategy with a bit of management, and,... guess what ? It's great fun !

Xcom uses a certain graphical style, which reminded me a bit of Team Fortress 2. It's not super detailed by any means, but I still liked the clean look of things.

The combat is brilliant, with the camera zooming in when a certain action is taken. It makes the combat feel exciting. Completing missions and killing enemies will level up your soldiers. You'll learn to take care of them, because when they're a higher level some of their abilities might just save you and your squad.

The story is nothing special, but the way the whole game is executed is just amazing. You'll have to make some difficult choices (concerning building certain items/facilities and the missions you choose to accept), none of which are right or wrong.

The sounds and music also add to the atmosphere of the entire game.

Also, for a single-player game it's surprisingly lenghty as well. It should take most players well over 20 hours to complete, especially if you mess up your first few games (like me).

Highly recommended !

[Rating: 90/100]

reviewText: I want to recommend this game so badly. It is absolutely a fantastic game and there is a good reason why it is so widely recommended. HOWEVER, I encountered so many rage inducing bugs and glitches that I cannot, in good faith, recommend  XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Enemies appearing out of thin air and killing nearby squadmates, a bizarre glitch that happens when you try to perform an action and then reload your weapon causing you to have to reload the mission, because you then cannot perform any further actions, and finally percentage values for aiming that are inaccurate. (I missed three shots that were 100% back to back to back). The saddest part is that, according to fans, many of these issues are solved if you fork out the cash for the expansion. It's not worth my keyboard, mouse, or a hole in the wall from these rage inducing issues. Considering I purchased the game years after release there is no chance that these bugs will be fixed unless I want to pay for an expansion that supposedly fixes these issues.

reviewText:
Enemy Unknown is the latest release to bring back the classic X-Com series. This time aliens have invaded Earth and are generally up to no good, and it's your job as Commander to stop them.

The game is turn based strategy through and through, although you do have to manage your base and your finances. You do this by keeping countries happy, which reduces panic, which in turn earns you cash. As you defeat the aliens you gain access to their technology which you can study and adapt to you own needs.

Most of the game-play elements from the classic series make a return, meaning that you will have to manage your base, keep an eye out for alien craft, build whatever you need and control any research whilst keeping a tight grip on your finances. As you progress your soldiers will become more skilled and generally more powerful, and as your study continues and gain access to more powerful equipment.

The game has multi-player too, so you can fight against human players as well as the computer controlled opponents. When you do send you soldiers to fight each player is given a â€œturnâ€ in which to move or shoot. The the general rule is that you have to find cover, and then shoot back. Your squad has other skills which you can use to adapt to the enemy's strategy. There are a lot of different aliens to blast, some of which are quite tough, especially in groups.

The game can be easily played with a controller or the more traditional keyboard and mouse. The game has a sort of way-point system which snaps to a grid. This works well for the most part, but the cursor can sometimes sort of â€œtwitchâ€ which means that your soldiers don't quite go where you want them to and crucially are not in cover. If you take you time and make sure it's where you want it before you click then it's OK.

Graphically the game is quite attractive although a little simple looking. Having said that most of the action takes place from an overhead perspective, and there can be a lot of enemies on screen â€“ especially in the later missions. The maps are not overly large, but are well designed and have many different features to take advantage of, giving you a lot of options during combat. Having said that there aren't really that many and you will fight in the same areas over and over â€“ even if they are supposed to be different countries.

The game should keep you busy for a while as there is plenty to do and an alien plot to uncover, but the small control problem and the limited locations can make it a little frustrating.
